PUBLIC WORKS FUNDS AND ACCOUNTS
§ 35.01 CONCESSION FUNDS.
   (A)   Pursuant to I.C. 36-1-3 et seq., there is now established in the
Office of the Clerk-Treasurer a non-reverting fund to be known as the
Department of Public Works Concession Fund. This Fund shall be under the
control of the Board of Public Works and Safety and is subject to the following
conditions.
      (1)   Monies from gifts to this Fund, receipts from scrapped items put
out by persons for city trash pick-up, and concessions sold from machines at
the Department of Public Works facility shall be accepted into the Fund.
      (2)   All disbursements made from this Fund shall be for or on behalf of
the Department of Public Works, and used for replenishing concession items,
providing food for city employees for a Departmental Christmas party, and as
needed for food and needed items for workers during state of emergency working
conditions and during safety training sessions and other work-related
functions, retirement parties, gifts, funeral flowers, employee awards and the
like. These disbursements shall be made on the order of the Board of Public
Works and Safety to the Clerk-Treasurer and payable upon presentation of proper
claims as specified in §
30.40 of the City Code.
   (B)   Pursuant to I.C. 36-1-3 et seq., there is now established in the
Office of the Clerk-Treasurer a non-reverting fund to be known as the City Hall
Concession Fund. This Fund shall be under the control of the Board of Public
Works and Safety and is subject to the following conditions:
      (1)   Monies from gifts to this Fund, receipts from sales of coffee, soda
and concessions sold from machines at City Hall shall be accepted into the
Fund.
      (2)   All disbursements made from this Fund shall be for replenishing
concession items, providing food for city employees for a Christmas party, and
as needed for food and needed items for city employees during training sessions
and other work-related functions, retirement parties, gifts, funeral flowers,
employee awards and the like. These disbursements shall be made on the order of
the Board of Public Works and Safety to the Clerk-Treasurer and payable upon
presentation of proper claims as specified in §
30.40 of the City Code.
   (C)   Pursuant to I.C. 36-1-3 et seq., there is now established in the
Office of the Clerk-Treasurer a non-reverting fund to be known as the Police
Department Concession Fund. This Fund shall be under the control of the Board
of Public Works and Safety and is subject to the following conditions:
      (1)   Monies from gifts to this Fund, receipts from sales of coffee, soda
and concessions sold from machines at Seymour Police Department headquarters
shall be accepted into the Fund.
      (2)   All disbursements made from this Fund shall be for replenishing
concession items, providing for a Police Department for a Christmas party, and
as needed for food and needed items for city employees during training sessions
and other work-related functions, retirement parties, gifts, funeral flowers,
employee awards and the like. These disbursements shall be made on the order of
the Board of Public Works and Safety to the Clerk-Treasurer and payable upon
presentation of proper claims as specified in § 30.40 of the City Code.
(1987 Code, § 2-170) (Ord. 54, 1996, passed 10-28-1996; Am. Ord. 10, 2013,
passed 7-8-2013)
§ 35.02 ALCOHOL AND DRUG ABUSE EDUCATION AND PREVENTION FUND.
   (A)   Pursuant to I.C. 36-1-3 et seq., there is now established in the
Office of the Clerk-Treasurer a non-reverting fund to be known as the Alcohol
and Drug Abuse Education and Prevention Fund.
   (B)   The Fund shall be under the control of the Board of Public Works and
Safety and is subject to the following conditions.
      (1)   Monies from gifts and appropriations shall be accepted into the
Fund.
      (2)   All disbursements from the Fund shall be for alcohol and drug abuse
education and prevention and shall be made on the order of the Board of Public
Works and Safety and payable by the Clerk-Treasurer upon presentation of proper
claims.
(1987 Code, § 2-174) (Ord. 14-83, passed 9-12-1983)
§ 35.03 LANDFILL COST FUND.
   (A)   The Clerk-Treasurer is directed to establish a non-reverting fund to
be known as the Landfill Cost Fund, which Fund shall be under the control of
the Director of Public Works and the Board of Public Works and Safety of the
city.
   (B)   All monies received from commercial garbage pick-up and from special
trash and garbage pick-ups, as determined by the Director of Public Works,
shall be deposited therein.
   (C)   All disbursements from the Fund shall be on the order of the Board of
Public Works and Safety and payable by the Clerk-Treasurer upon the
presentation of proper claims, approved by the Board of Public Works and
Safety.
   (D)   This Fund is established pursuant to I.C. 36-1-3 et seq., Home Rule.
(1987 Code, § 2-177) (Ord. 7, 1989, passed 7-10-1989)
§ 35.04 TRANSIT FUND.
   (A)   There is established in the Office of the Clerk-Treasurer of the city
a non-reverting fund known as the Transit Fund, pursuant to I.C. 36-1-3 et seq.
The Fund is to be controlled by the Director of Public Works and Board of
Public Works and Safety.
   (B)   (1)   The purpose of the Transit Fund is for the payment of the Parks
and Recreation Department’s portion of the costs related to the operations,
reporting, and compliance with federal and state regulations.
      (2)   The Transit Fund will have the additional stated purpose of being
the repository of receipts, reimbursements, and funding of the Department’s bus
(es). The funds deposited in the account will be used for the operations and
maintenance of the Department’s bus(es).
   (C)   All disbursements from the Transit Fund shall be for the purposes
stated above as defined by the grant received by the city. These disbursements
shall be made upon the order of the Board of Public Works and Safety and
payable by the Clerk-Treasurer upon presentation of proper claims.
(1987 Code, § 2-178) (Ord. 9, 1988, passed 5-9-1988; Am. Ord. 10, 1992, passed
3-23-1992)
§ 35.05 ACCIDENT REPORT ACCOUNT; FEES.
   (A)   The fee for each accident report shall be as set forth in
Ch. 36 of this code.
   (B)   Pursuant to state law, there is now established in the Office of the
Clerk-Treasurer a non-reverting account known as the Accident Report Account,
which Account shall be under the control of the Board of Public Works and
Safety and is subject to the following conditions.
      (1)   All monies received in accident report fees shall be deposited
therein.
      (2)   All disbursements from the Account shall be for the purposes
hereinabove stated and made on the order of the Board of Public Works and
Safety and payable by the Clerk-Treasurer upon presentation of proper claims,
approved as other claims of the Board are approved.
(1987 Code, § 2-179) (Ord. 18-81, passed 8-10-1981)
§ 35.06 PETTY CASH FUND.
   (A)   There is hereby established in the Office of the Clerk-Treasurer a
fund known as the "Seymour Department of Public Works Petty Cash Fund,"
pursuant to I.C. 36-1-3 et seq. This fund is separate from the city’s General
Fund and money in the "Seymour Department of Public Works Petty Cash Fund" at
the end of a fiscal year does not revert to the city’s General Fund or to any
other fund.
   (B)   The purpose of the Petty Cash Fund is for the payment of minor,
miscellaneous expenses of the Department of Public Works. The Fund is to be
under direct supervision and control of the Director of the Department of
Public Works.
   (C)   Distribution of money from the fund shall be made without the
necessity of first obtaining and appropriation from the City Council.
   (D)   The total cash on hand in the fund shall not exceed the sum of $100.
   (E)   The Fund shall be reimbursed, on a line item basis, at the next
available claims period for each amount used.
   (F)   All disbursements from the Fund shall be for the purposes stated
above. Theses disbursements shall be made upon the directive of the Director of
the Department of Public Works and shall be the sole responsibility of the
Director.
(Ord. 23, 2011, passed 11-28-2011)
§ 35.07 SMSU ON-LINE ACCOUNT.
   (A)   There is now established in the Office of the Clerk-Treasurer a fund
to be known as the SMSU On-Line Account.
   (B)   All monies received from credit card or debit card payments made to
the Seymour Municipal Sanitation Utility (SMSU) shall be deposited into this
account.
   (C)   At least one time per month the Clerk- Treasurer shall transfer all
monies held in the SMSU On-Line Account to the appropriate line item(s) in the
SMSU Operating Fund.
(Ord. 5, 2018, passed 5-29-2018)
§ 35.08 SIDEWALK FUND.
   (A)   There is now established in the Office of the Clerk-Treasurer a non-
reverting fund to be known as the Sidewalk Fund.
   (B)   This Fund shall be under the control of the Department of Public
Works, and is subject to the following conditions:
      (1)   All monies received from donations for the construction,
reconstruction and maintenance of public sidewalks and curbs shall be accepted
and deposited into the Fund.
      (2)   The sum of $15,000 shall be deposited by the Clerk-Treasurer in the
Sidewalk Fund as previously established by the City Council.
      (3)   All disbursements made from this Fund shall be for or on behalf of
the Department of Public Works, and used solely for construction,
reconstruction and maintenance of public sidewalks and curbs within the
boundaries of the city, and in accordance with the rules established by the
Board of Public Works and Safety for the Shared Cost Sidewalk Program. These
disbursements shall be made on the order of the Board of Public Works and
Safety to the Clerk-Treasurer, and payable to applicant upon presentation of
proper claims as specified in § 30.40 of the City Code.
(Ord. 18, 2015, passed 5-26-2015; Am. Ord. 5, 2018, passed 5-29-2018; Am. Ord.
8, 2023, passed 4-10-2023)
§ 35.09 TRANSIT OPERATIONAL RESERVE FUND.
   (A)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall create and maintain a fund for the receipt
and disbursement of funds for purchasing of city transit vehicles. Said Fund
shall be entitled the Transit Operational Reserve Fund.
   (B)   The moneys deposited in the Fund shall not revert to the General Fund
from time to time, but rather shall be non-reverting and continue perpetually
until further order of the Common Council.
   (C)   The purpose of this Fund shall be consistent with grant agreements and
state and federal regulations, as applicable, as well as the Transit Operating
Reserve Policy.
   (D)   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall be vested with the
responsibility and discretion for making expenditures from this Fund in
accordance with applicable law and without need for appropriation or budgeting,
it being understood that this Fund supports a transit program operating under
state and federal regulations and grant agreements developed pursuant thereto.
(Res. 19, 2020, passed 7-13-2020)

§ 35.15 DEPARTMENT PETTY CASH FUND.
   (A)   There is established in the Office of the Clerk-Treasurer of the city
a non-reverting fund known as the Parks and Recreation Department Petty Cash
Fund, pursuant to I.C. 36-1-3 et seq. The Fund is to be controlled by the
Superintendent of Parks and Recreation and the Parks and Recreation Board.
   (B)   The purpose of the Petty Cash Fund is for the payment of fees to
sports league officials for officiating games and recreational activities
supervised by the Parks and Recreation Department for the various athletic
leagues, tournaments, and other events conducted by or under the direction of
the Department. Distribution of money from the Petty Cash Fund shall be made
without the necessity of first obtaining an appropriation from the City
Council.
   (C)   All disbursements from the Petty Cash Fund shall be for the purposes
stated above. These disbursements shall be made upon the directive of the Parks
and Recreation Department Director and shall be the sole responsibility of the
Director and his or her staff.
(1987 Code, § 2-172) (Ord. 42, 1990, passed 12-10-1990)
§ 35.16 LEAGUE FEE ASSESSMENT FUND.
   (A)   There is now established in the Office of the Clerk-Treasurer of the
city a non-reverting fund known as the Parks and Recreation Department League
Fee Assessment Fund, pursuant to I.C. 36-1-3 et seq. The Fund is to be
controlled by the Superintendent of Parks and Recreation and the Parks and
Recreation Board.
   (B)   The purpose of the League Fee Assessment Fund is for the collection
and deposit of dues, fees, and assessments of any kind or character levied by
the Parks and Recreation Department for the various athletic leagues,
tournaments, and other events conducted by or under the direction of the
Department.
      (1)   The funds are derived from fees, dues, and assessments paid by
league participants in athletic events conducted by or under the direction of
the Department.
      (2)   Distribution of money from the League Fee Assessment Fund shall be
made without the necessity of first obtaining appropriation from the City
Council. To make a claim the Parks and Recreation Department will submit to the
Clerk-Treasurer of the city a standard claim form as prescribed by the state
Board of Accounts.
      (3)   All monies derived from these fees shall be utilized for league
expenses, including, but not limited to, scorekeepers, umpires, equipment,
awards, supervisors, and supplies.
   (C)   All disbursements from the League Fee Assessment Fund shall be for the
purposes stated above. These disbursements shall be made upon the order of the
Board of Public Works and Safety and payable by the Clerk-Treasurer upon
presentation of proper claims.
(1987 Code, § 2-173) (Ord. 4, 1990, passed 3-12-1990)
§ 35.17 COMMUNITY CENTER MAINTENANCE AND UTILITY FUND.
   (A)   Pursuant to I.C. 36-1-3 et seq., there is now established in the
Office of the City Clerk-Treasurer a non-reverting fund to be known as the
Community Center Maintenance and Utility Fund.
   (B)   This Fund shall be under the control of the Board of Parks and
Recreation of the city, and the Fund is subject to the following conditions:
      (1)   All monies received from the operation and use of the Community
Center shall be deposited therein;
      (2)   All monies received from donations for utilities and maintenance of
the Community Center shall be deposited therein; and
      (3)   All disbursements from the Fund shall be on the order of the Board
of Parks and Recreations of the city and payable by the City Clerk-Treasurer
upon presentation of proper claims, approved as other claims of the Board are
approved.
(1987 Code, § 2-182) (Ord. 8-80, passed 3-24-1980)
§ 35.18 BUS MAINTENANCE ACCOUNT.
   (A)   The City Clerk-Treasurer is expressly authorized to establish, as a
new and separate account, a Bus Maintenance Account.
   (B)   The City Clerk-Treasurer is expressly so authorized, empowered, and
directed to deposit in this Account, as heretofore established, any and all
donations as received by the Parks and Recreation Department, its servants,
employees, and agents, or any other department or agency of the city, funds
donated for the maintenance of the bus to be receipted into the Bus Maintenance
Account, it being further directed that no monies received by the city from
other sources shall be commingled therewith.
   (C)   After the Account is established, the City Clerk-Treasurer is
expressly authorized to disburse from the account, on proper claims, approved
by the Board of Public Works and Safety as other claims are approved, without
specific appropriation thereof, the disbursements to be made only for the
specific purpose, or purposes, of the fund.
(1987 Code, § 2-184) (Res. 9-78, passed 3-13-1978)

AIRPORT FUNDS
§ 35.30 AIRPORT RAILROAD MAINTENANCE FUND.
   (A)   Pursuant to I.C. 36-1-3 et seq., there is now established in the
Office of the Clerk-Treasurer a non-reverting fund to be known as the Airport
Railroad Maintenance Fund.
   (B)   This Fund shall be under the control of the Airport Authority of the
city, and the Fund shall be more conditioned as follows:
      (1)   All monies received from the operation and use of the Freeman Field
railroad spur shall be deposited therein;
      (2)   In addition thereto, in case of need for capital expenditures in
excess of amounts available from the Fund, the Airport Authority may
temporarily deposit in the Fund other sums derived from its general operations,
subject to budgetary authorization thereof, and which sums, as so advanced,
shall be returned to the regular accounts of the Airport Authority as and when
the balance in the Airport Railroad Maintenance Fund is sufficient to permit
the return thereof, as aforementioned; and
      (3)   All disbursements from the Fund shall be on the order of the
Airport Authority and payable by the City Clerk-Treasurer upon presentation of
proper claims, approved as other claims of the Airport Authority are approved.
(1987 Code, § 2-183) (Ord. 11-79, passed 5-28-1979; Am. Ord. 4, 1993, passed 2-
8-1993)
§ 35.31 MUNICIPAL AIRPORT AUTHORITY CONCESSION FUND.
   (A)   There shall be established a non-reverting Municipal Airport Authority
Concession Fund for receipt of monies from:
      (1)   Recyclable or scrap items set out by companies or persons for
disposal or pick-up;
      (2)   Scrap metal from repairs and renovations at various sites and
locations at Freeman Field Airport and Industrial Park; and
      (3)   Donations.
   (B)   Revenues from these sources shall be accepted into the non-reverting
Municipal Airport Authority Concession Fund in which to place monies realized
from this program by the Municipal Airport Authority.
   (C)   All monies received and spent will be for and on behalf of the
Municipal Airport Authority, and used for providing food for city employees for
Departmental functions, and other necessary items for workers during state of
emergency working conditions and during education, safety, and training
sessions and other work-related functions, or to be used as designated by the
individual or corporate donor(s).
   (D)   All expenditures from this Fund shall first be approved utilizing the
following procedure:
      (1)   The donor of any individual or corporate contribution shall receive
a receipt from the Airport Manager or Clerk-Treasurer;
      (2)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall utilize the collection form specified by
the state Board of Accounts;
      (3)   The expenditure shall be approved by the Municipal Airport
Authority;
      (4)   The expenditure shall then be approved by the Board of Public Works
and Safety; and
      (5)   No expenditure shall be approved without submission of the proper
claim form specified by the Clerk-Treasurer.
(Ord. 30, 2001, passed 11-12-2001)

FIRE DEPARTMENT FUNDS
§ 35.45 CUMULATIVE FIRE DEPARTMENT BUILDING, EQUIPMENT, AND FIREFIGHTING FUND.
   (A)   The Cumulative Fire Department Building and Equipment Fund and the
Cumulative Firefighting Fund are combined into one fund known as the Cumulative
Fire Department Building, Equipment, and Firefighting Fund.
   (B)   This Fund shall be used for the following purposes: the purchase,
construction, renovation, or addition to buildings used by the Fire Department
and for the purchase of firefighting equipment, including making the required
payments under a lease rental with the option to purchase and acquire
equipment, and for all other purposes allowed by I.C. 36-8-14-1 et seq.
   (C)   The levying of an additional tax at the rate of $0.10 on each $100 of
taxable real and personal property within the taxing district shall continue to
be imposed to provide monies for the Fund until reduced or rescinded, as
provided in I.C. 36-8-14-1 et seq.
(1987 Code, § 2-181) (Ord. 7-84, passed 4-9-1984; Ord. 34, 1987, passed 12-14-
1987)
§ 35.46 HAZARDOUS WASTE CLEAN-UP FUND.
   (A)   There is established in the Office of the Clerk-Treasurer of the city
a non-reverting fund known as the city Fire Department Hazardous Waste Clean-Up
Fund, pursuant to I.C. 36-1-3 et seq. The Fund is to be controlled by the Chief
of the city Fire Department.
   (B)   The purpose of the Hazardous Waste Clean-Up Fund is for the receipt of
monies received for hazardous waste clean-up conducted by the Fire Department.
   (C)   All claims for disbursement from this Fund must be approved by the
Board of Public Works and Safety. Distribution of money from the Hazardous
Waste Clean-Up Fund shall be made without the necessity of first obtaining an
appropriation from the City Council.
   (D)   Monies from the Hazardous Waste Clean-up Fund shall be utilized for
the following purposes only:
      (1)   Hazardous waste education;
      (2)   Hazardous waste training; and
      (3)   To replace hazardous waste equipment.
   (E)   A hazardous materials response fee structure shall be implemented for
the use of the city’s services as set forth in
Ch. 36 of this code.
(1987 Code, § 2-191) (Ord. 2, 1995, passed 2-20-1995)
POLICE DEPARTMENT FUNDS
§ 35.60 LAW ENFORCEMENT CONTINUING EDUCATION FUND.
   (A)   There is established in the Office of the Clerk-Treasurer of the city
a non-reverting fund known as the Law Enforcement Continuing Education Fund,
pursuant to I.C. 36-1-3 et seq. The Fund is to be controlled by the Chief of
Police and the Board of Public Works and Safety.
   (B)   The purpose of the Law Enforcement Continuing Education Fund is for
the payment of training costs for the city Police Department and its officers
pursuant to I.C. 5-2-1 et seq.
      (1)   The funds are derived from court costs paid to the County Clerk by
defendants in the Circuit Court and Superior Court.
      (2)   Distribution of money for the Law Enforcement Continuing Education
Fund shall be made without the necessity of first obtaining an appropriation
from the City Council. To make a claim, the city Police Department will submit
to the County Auditor a verified statement of case numbers for fees collected
that are attributable to the efforts of the city Police Department. The city
Police Department shall submit this claim for fees in the same fiscal year in
which the fees are collected.
      (3)   All monies derived from these fees shall be utilized for the
continuing education and training of officers of the city Police Department.
   (C)   All disbursements from the Continuing Education Fund shall be for the
purposes stated above as defined by the Indiana Code. These disbursements shall
be made upon the order of the Board of Public Works and Safety and payable by
the Clerk-Treasurer upon presentation of proper claims.
(1987 Code, § 2-176) (Ord. 28, 1989, passed 9-25-1989)
§ 35.61 POLICE EQUIPMENT, FIREARMS TRAINING, AND PROCEDURAL TRAINING FUND.
   (A)   Pursuant to I.C. 35-47-2-3 and 36-1-3 et seq., the former non-
reverting funds formerly known as the Firearms Training Fund and the Police
Equipment and Training Benefaction Fund are combined into one fund known as the
Police Equipment, Firearms Training, and Procedural Training Non-Reverting
Fund.
   (B)   All monies received from applicants for handgun licenses shall be
deposited into this non-reverting Fund. All donations to the Police Department
shall also be deposited into this non-reverting Fund.
   (C)   All disbursements from this Fund shall be for the purposes hereinabove
stated and made on the order of the Board of Public Works and Safety, payable
by the Clerk-Treasurer upon the presentation of proper claims, and approved as
other claims of the Board are approved.
(1987 Code, § 2-180) (Ord. 19-81, passed 8-10-1981; Am. Ord. 34, 1987, passed
12-14-1987)

§ 35.62 FORFEITURE FUND.
   (A)   Pursuant to I.C. 36, the City Council creates a non-reverting fund for
accumulation of assets recovered, seized, and forfeited by the city Police
Department during criminal investigations to be known as the city Police
Department Forfeiture Fund.
   (B)   The funds accumulated in the city Police Department Forfeiture Fund
shall be utilized only for those purposes set forth in the U.S. Code and the
Indiana Code governing the recovery, seizure, and forfeiture of assets
accumulated during the investigation of criminal felons and misdemeanants.

§ 35.63 PETTY CASH FUND.
   (A)   There is established in the Office of the Clerk-Treasurer of the city
a non-reverting fund known as the city Police Department Petty Cash Fund,
pursuant to I.C. 36-1-3 et seq. The Fund is to be controlled by the Chief of
the city Police Department.
   (B)   The purpose of the Petty Cash Fund is for the payment of postage,
travel expense advancements, and other miscellaneous expenses.
   (C)   Distribution of money from the Petty Cash Fund shall be made without
the necessity of first obtaining an appropriation from the City Council.
   (D)   The total Fund, cash on hand, shall not exceed the sum of $150.
    (E)   The Fund shall be reimbursed, on a line item basis, at the next
available claims period for each amount used.
    (F)   All disbursements from the Petty Cash Fund shall be for the purposes
stated above. These disbursements shall be made upon the directive of the Chief
of the city Police Department and shall be the sole responsibility of the Chief
and his or her staff.

§ 35.67 EXPENDITURE OF CONFIDENTIAL FUNDS.
   (A)   The procedure set out in this section shall be applicable to all
expenditures by the Seymour Police Department that are needed in the course of
criminal investigations to pay informants for information, make drug purchases,
or other purchases in order to gather evidence to make an arrest. These
procedures shall be used for all such expenditures, no matter the source of the
monies that are being expended, including, but not limited to forfeiture funds,
grant funds or tax funds.
   (B)   Appropriation for such purpose must be obtained in the manner
authorized by state statutes.
   (C)   If petty cash funds are used, procedures set out in I.C. 36-1-8-3 must
be followed.
   (D)   A minimum documentation procedure must be followed, similar to either:
      (1)   "Guidelines for the Expenditure of Confidential Funds," published
by the U.S. Department of Criminal Justice, or
      (2)   "Guidelines for Obtaining and Accounting for Confidential Funds
Used in Support of Criminal Investigations," (Revised S.O.P. PR-INV-0017), by
the Indiana State Police Department.
(Ord. 7, 2017, passed 3-27-2017)

GENERAL FUNDS
§ 35.80 CITY PROMOTIONAL FUND.
   (A)   A fund known as the city Promotional Fund is established. The City
Council is authorized to budget and appropriate funds from the General Fund or
from other funds to the Promotional Fund to pay expenses which are deemed by
the Mayor to directly relate to the promotion or betterment of the city.
   (B)   The City Council is further authorized to budget and appropriate funds
from the General Fund or from other funds to individual departmental budgets to
provide for membership fees for the city and the elected and appointed
officials and members of various municipal boards, councils, departments, or
agencies in local, regional, state, and national associations of a civic,
educational, or governmental nature which have as their purpose the betterment
and improvement of municipal operations.
   (C)   The City Council is further authorized to budget and appropriate funds
to pay the expenses of duly authorized representatives to attend the meetings
and functions of organizations to which the municipality belongs.
(1987 Code, § 2-175) (Ord. 14-82, passed 8-9-1982)
§ 35.81 CUMULATIVE CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT FUND.
   (A)   There is created a special fund to be known as the Cumulative Capital
Improvement Fund of the city, into which the cigarette taxes allotted to the
city by reason of the state Cigarette Tax Law being I.C. 6-7-1, as amended,
shall be deposited. This Fund shall be a cumulative fund and all of the monies
deposited into the Fund shall be appropriated and used solely for capital
improvements as hereinafter defined, and none of the monies shall revert to the
General Fund or be used for any purposes other than capital improvements.
   (B)   For the purpose of this section, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS.
         (a)   The construction or improvement of any property owned by the
city, including but not limited to streets, thoroughfares, and sewers, and the
retirement of general obligation bonds of the city, issued, and the proceeds
used for the purpose of construction capital improvements.
         (b)   The term shall not include salaries of any public officials or
employees except those which are directly chargeable to a capital improvement.
(1987 Code, § 2-186) (Ord. 1448, passed 11-29-1965)
§ 35.82 CITY ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION FUND.
   (A)   The Clerk-Treasurer is directed to establish a non-reverting fund to
be known as the city Economic Development Commission Fund, which Fund shall be
under the control of the Economic Development Commission of the city.
   (B)   All monies received from the operation of the Economic Development
Commission, including but not limited to application fees, appropriations, or
levies, shall be deposited therein.
   (C)   All disbursements from the Fund shall be on the order of the Economic
Development Commission and payable by the Clerk-Treasurer upon the presentation
of proper claims, approved by the Economic Development Commission.
   (D)   This fund is established pursuant to I.C. 36-1-3 et seq., Home Rule.
(1987 Code, § 2-187) (Ord. 32, 1987, passed 11-23-1987)
§ 35.83 CUMULATIVE CAPITAL DEVELOPMENT FUND.
   (A)   Application. This section applies to the city.
    (B)   Authorization of Fund purpose. The City Council, with the approval of
the state Board of Tax Commissioners, establishes a Cumulative Capital
Development Fund to provide money for which purpose for the property taxes may
be imposed within the municipality under the authority of: I.C. 8-16-3, Bridges
and Tunnels; I.C. 8-22-3-25, Airport Authorities; I.C. 14-33-1 et seq.,
Conservancy Districts; I.C. 16-23-1 et seq., City Hospitals; I.C. 36-8-14,
Cumulative Building and Equipment Fund; I.C. 36-9-4-48, Urban Mass
Transportation; I.C. 36-9-16-2, Cumulative Building Fund; I.C. 36-9-16-3,
Cumulative Capital Improvement Fund; I.C. 36-9-16.5, Cumulative Street Fund;
I.C. 36-9-17, General Improvement Fund; I.C. 36-9-26, Cumulative Sewer Building
Fund; or I.C. 36-10-3-21 or 36-10-4-36, Parks Building Fund.
   (C)   Notice and hearing on proposed Fund.
      (1)   The city, in establishing a Cumulative Capital Development Fund,
shall:
         (a)   Give notice of the proposal to the affected taxpayers; and
         (b)   Hold a public hearing on the proposal before presenting it to
the state Board of Tax Commissioners for approval.
      (2)   Notice of the proposal and of the public hearing shall be given by
publication in accordance with I.C. 5-14-1.5-5.
   (D)   Submission to Tax Commissioners; notice; objections; hearings;
decisions.
      (1)   If, after the public hearing held under division (C) of this
section, the proposal is submitted for approval to the state Board of Tax
Commissioners, the Board shall require notice of the submission to be given to
the taxpayer of the municipality in the manner prescribed by division (C)(2) of
this section. Fifty or more of the taxpayers in the municipality may file a
petition setting forth their objections to the proposed levy with the County
Auditor not later than 30 days after the publication under this division.
       (2)   The County Auditor shall immediately certify a petition filed
under division (D)(1) above to the state Board of Tax Commissioners. The Board
shall, within a reasonable time, fix a date for a hearing on the petition,
which shall be held in the affected municipality. Notice of the hearing shall
be given to the County Auditor and to the first ten taxpayers whose names
appear upon the petition by a letter that is signed by the secretary or any
member of the Board and mailed to the Auditor and the taxpayers at their usual
place of residence at least five days before the date fixed for the hearing.
      (3)   After the hearing, the state Board of Tax Commissioners shall
certify its approval, disapproval, or modification of the proposal to the
Auditor of the county. The action of the Board with respect to the proposed
levy is final and conclusive.
   (E)   Municipal plans; presentation in notice and hearings. In the notice
provided to the public and at the required hearings, the municipality shall
present a plan that describes the tax levy that will impose for the fund, the
length of time (up to a maximum of three years) during which the municipality
plans to impose a property tax under this section, and the use that the
municipality plans to make of the taxes raised.
   (F)   Tax levy; rate of tax.
      (1)   The municipal fiscal body shall provide money for the Cumulative
Capital Development Fund by levying a tax on the taxable property in the
municipality.
      (2)   The maximum property tax rate that may be imposed for property
taxes first due and payable during a particular year in a municipality that is
either wholly or partially located in a county in which the county option
income tax or the county adjusted gross income tax is in effect on January 1 of
that year depends upon the number of years the municipality has previously
imposed a tax under this chapter and is determined under the following table:
 
Number of Years Maximum Tax Rate per $100 of Assessed Valuation
0               $0.05
1               $0.10
2 or more       $0.15
 
      (3)   Beginning with the first annual tax levy after the state Board of
Tax Commissioners approves the tax rate, the municipal fiscal body may levy the
tax annually for any period not exceeding three years. A tax levy under this
section must be advertised annually in the same manner as other tax levies.
      (4)   After a tax levy has been imposed under this section for the period
approved by the state Board of Tax Commissioners, a new tax levy may not be
imposed under the authority of this section until the municipality has complied
with the hearing and notice requirements provided by this section for the
establishment of a Cumulative Capital Development Fund.
   (G)   Reduction or rescission of tax levy.
      (1)   A municipal legislative body may reduce or rescind a tax levy made
under division (F) of this section.
      (2)   Fifty or more taxpayers in the municipality may file with the
County Auditor, not later than August 1 of any year, a petition for reduction
or rescission of a tax levy made under division (F) of this section. The
petition must set forth the taxpayers’ objections to the levy and be certified
to the state Board of Tax Commissioners. The Board shall give notice and
conduct a hearing in the manner prescribed by division (D) of this section.
After the hearing, the Board may reduce or rescind the levy, and its action is
final and conclusive.
   (H)   Deposits and expenditures.
      (1)   The tax money collected under this section shall be held in a
special fund to be known as the Cumulative Capital Development Fund. The money
may not be expended for any purpose other than the purpose for which the tax
was levied.
       (2)   Expenditures from the Cumulative Capital Development Fund may be
made only after an appropriation made in the manner provided by law for making
other appropriations.
       (3)   Notwithstanding divisions (H)(1) and (H)(2), money held in the
Cumulative Capital Development Fund may be spent for purposes other than the
purposes stated in division (B) of this section, if the purpose is to protect
the public health, welfare, or safety in an emergency situation that demands
immediate action or to make a contribution to an authority established under
I.C. 36-7-23, money may be spent under the authority of this division only
after the executive of the municipality:
         (a)   Issues a declaration that the public health, welfare, or safety
is in immediate danger that requires the expenditure of money in the Fund; or
         (b)   Certifies in the minutes of the municipal legislative body that
the contribution is made to the authority for capital development purposes.
(1987 Code, § 2-195) (Ord. 18, 1992, passed 6-8-1992)
§ 35.84 BUILDING COMMISSIONER UNSAFE STRUCTURES FUND.
   (A)   There is now established in the Office of the Clerk-Treasurer of the
city a non-reverting fund known as the Building Commissioner Unsafe Structures
Fund, pursuant to I.C. 36-1-3 et seq. The Fund is to be controlled by the
Building Commissioner for the city.
   (B)   (1)   The purpose of the Unsafe Structures Fund is for payment of the
costs associated with the demolition and clean-up of unsafe properties and
structures as ordered by the Building Commissioner for the city.
      (2)   The funds are to be derived from the following sources:
         (a)   Building permit fees;
         (b)   Improvement location permit fees;
         (c)   Certificates of occupancy;
         (d)   Fees generated by the Board of Zoning Appeals and the Plan
Commission (i.e., application fees for a variance or rezoning, as well as plat
fees);
         (e)   Monies generated from the sale of code books; and
         (f)   Monies generated from the sale of zoning maps.
      (3)   Distribution of money from the Building Commissioner Unsafe
Structures Fund shall be made without the necessity of first obtaining an
appropriation from the City Council. To make a claim the Building Commissioner
will submit to the Clerk-Treasurer for the city a standard claim form as
prescribed by the state Board of Accounts.
      (4)   Monies derived from the above named sources shall be utilized for
costs expended in the demolition and clean-up of unsafe properties and
structures.
      (5)   Any additional funds may be utilized for the purchase of office
equipment to help in the management of the Department and this Fund.
   (C)   All disbursements from the Building Commissioner Unsafe Structure Fund
shall be for the purposes stated above. These disbursements shall be made upon
the order of the Board of Public Works and Safety and payable by the Clerk-
Treasurer upon presentation of proper claims.
(1987 Code, § 2-189) (Ord. 7, 1991, passed 2-25-1991)
§ 35.85 ELECTRICAL TRAINING PROGRAM FUND.
   (A)   There is created an Electrical Training Program non-reverting fund for
deposit of all fees for licenses collected pursuant to
Ch. 152 of this code.
   (B)   All claims for payment from this Fund shall be submitted to the Clerk-
Treasurer by the Building Commissioner and must be approved by two members of
the Board of Public Works and Safety.
   (C)   Education paid for from the fund monies can be any educational classes
or programs beneficial to the Planning and Zoning department and are not
limited to electrical education classes.
   (D)   The fund shall be permitted to have a maximum amount of $12,000.
   (E)   In the event that the fund accumulates more than $12,000, an annual
transfer of excess funds shall be made to the city’s general fund. Such
transfer should occur on or before April 30 of each calendar year.
(1987 Code, § 2-197) (Ord. 30, 1993, passed 9-27-1993; Am. Ord. 35, 2004,
passed 12-13-2004)
§ 35.86 GRANTS HOLDING FUND.
   (A)   The Clerk-Treasurer of the city shall create and maintain a fund for
the retention of grant funds received from federal and state agencies until
their disbursement according to the provisions of grant related agreements, and
for the retention of grant program related income. This fund shall be entitled
the Grants Holding Fund.
   (B)   The monies deposited in a Fund created under division (A) shall not
revert to the General Fund from time to time, but rather shall be non-reverting
and continue perpetually until further order of the City Council.
   (C)   The purpose of this Fund shall be for the undertaking of economic and
community development activities consistent with the controlling grant
agreement(s) where applicable, or as approved by the Board of Public Works and
Safety.
   (D)   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall be vested with the
responsibility and discretion of making expenditures from this Fund in
accordance with applicable law.
(1987 Code, § 2-192) (Ord. 20, 1993, passed 7-26-1993)

      (8)   Eastside Industrial Park;
      (9)   Region XI; and
      (10)   Federal Revenue Sharing Trust Fund.
      (11)   Federal Seizure, Fund 602; and
      (12)   Curb Appeal Program, Fund 231.
(1987 Code, §2-188) (Ord. 34, 1987, passed 12-14-1987; Am. Ord. 4, 2021, passed
2-8-2021; Am. Ord. 7, 2021, passed 3-22-2021)
§ 35.89 ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT INCOME TAX FUND.
   (A)   The city hereby creates an Economic Development Income Tax Fund for
the purpose of receipt of its share of the County Economic Development Income
Tax levy pursuant to I.C. 6-3.6.
   (B)   Revenues from the County Economic Development Income Tax will be paid
into and retained in the city Economic Development Income Tax Fund until spent
pursuant to its Capital Improvement Plan.
(Ord. 12, 2003, passed 7-28-2003)
§ 35.90 RAINY DAY FUND.
   (A)   There is hereby established a fund known as the “Rainy Day Fund.” This
fund is separate from the city’s General Fund, and money in the Rainy Day Fund
at the end of a fiscal year does not revert to the city’s General Fund or to
any other fund.
   (B)   Sources of funding for the Rainy Day Fund may include the following:
      (1)   Unused and unencumbered funds under:
         (a)   I.C. 36-1-8-5; or
         (b)   I.C. 6-3.6-9-15.
      (2) Any other funding source:
         (a)   As directed by the Seymour Common Council; and
         (b)   Not otherwise prohibited by law.
   (C)   Money in the Rainy Day Fund may be expended for any lawful municipal
public purpose upon appropriation by the Seymour Common Council using the same
appropriation process as other funds that receive tax money.
(Ord. 6, 2008, passed 2-25-2008)
§ 35.91 CUMULATIVE BUILDING OR REMODELING, FIREFIGHTING AND POLICE RADIO FUND.
   (A)   There is hereby established a fund known as the Cumulative Building or
Remodeling, Firefighting and Police Radio Fund for all uses as set out in I.C.
36-8-14-2(c).
   (B)   This Council will adhere to the provisions of I.C. 36-8-14. The
proposed fund will not exceed $0.0333 on each $100 of assessed valuation. Said
tax rate will be levied beginning with taxes for 2010 payable 2011.
   (C)   Said Cumulative Fund is subject to the approval of the Department of
Local Government Finance.
(Res. 13, 2010, passed 7-12-2010)
§ 35.92 LOIT SPECIAL DISTRIBUTION FUND.
   (A)   There is now established in the Office of the Clerk-Treasurer a non-
reverting fund to be known as the LOIT Special Distribution Fund.
   (B)   This Fund shall be subject to the following conditions:
      (1)   At least 75% of monies received in 2016 from a one-time special
distribution of LOIT (local option income taxes) pursuant to I.C. 6-3.6-9-17
shall be accepted and deposited into the Fund.
      (2)   All disbursements made from this Fund shall be exclusively for the
following purposes:
         (a)   Engineering, land acquisition, construction, resurfacing,
maintenance, restoration, or rehabilitation of both local and arterial road and
street systems;
         (b)   The payment of principal and interest on bonds sold primarily to
finance road, street, or thoroughfare projects;
         (c)   Any local costs required to undertake a recreational or
reservoir road project under I.C. 8-23-5;
         (d)   The purchase, rental, or repair of highway equipment;
         (e)   Providing a match for a grant from the local road and bridge
matching grant fund under I.C. 8-23-30; or
         (f)   Capital projects for aviation related property or facilities,
including capital projects of a Board of Aviation Commissioners established
under I.C. 8-22-2 or an Airport Authority established under I.C. 8-22-3-1.
   (C)   These disbursements shall be made on the order of the Board of Public
Works and Safety to the Clerk-Treasurer and payable upon presentation of proper
claims as specified in § 30.40.
(Ord. 7, 2016, passed 5-23-2016)
§ 35.93 PLANNING AND ZONING ON-LINE ACCOUNT.
   (A)   There is now established in the Office of the Clerk-Treasurer a fund
to be known as the Planning and Zoning On-Line Account.
   (B)   All monies received from credit card or debit card payments made to
the Planning and Zoning Department shall be deposited into this account.
   (C)   At least one time per month the Clerk- Treasurer shall transfer all
monies held in the Planning and Zoning On-Line Account to the appropriate line
item(s) in the Planning and Zoning section of the city’s General Fund.
(Ord. 5, 2018, passed 5-29-2018)
§ 35.94 CUMULATIVE CAPITAL FUND.
   (A)   For all uses set out in I.C. 36-9-15.5.
   (B)   This Council will adhere to the provisions of I.C. 36-9-15.5. The
proposed fund will not exceed $0.0500 on each $100 of assessed valuation. Said
tax rate will be levied beginning with taxes for 2022 payable 2023.
(Ord. 3, 2022, passed 2-28-2022)
