(1987 Code, § 8-67) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969; Am. Ord. 4, 2001, passed 2-
26-2001)
§ 71.032 PLAY STREETS; RESTRICTIONS; EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   Board designation. The Board of Public Works and Safety of the city,
by proper resolution, duly entered of record, and after notice by publication
thereof, may declare any street, or part of a street, a play street, the
periods of times of which shall be fixed by the Board in its resolution.
(1987 Code, § 8-88)
   (B)   Driving prohibited; exceptions. Whenever official signs are so erected
indicating any street or part of a street is a play street, no person shall
drive a vehicle upon any thus designated street, or portion thereof, except
drivers of vehicles whose residences are within the closed area, and then any
exempt driver shall exercise the greatest care in driving upon any play street,
or portion thereof.
(1987 Code, § 8-89)
(Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.033 QUIET ZONES; RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   Board designation of quiet zones. The Board of Public Works and Safety
of the city, by proper resolution, duly entered of record, and after notice by
publication thereof, may declare any street, or part of any street, or any
specific area, near or adjacent to a public or parochial school, any hospital,
any nursing or convalescent home, to be a quiet zone.
(1987 Code, § 8-91)
   (B)   Loud noises prohibited in quiet zones. When official signs are so
erected indicating that a street, or part of a street, or a specific area has
been so designated as a quiet zone, any loud or unusual noise by any person
within that zone shall be unlawful.
(1987 Code, § 8-92)
(Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.034 LANE AND CROSSWALK DESIGNATION; SIGNS, MARKERS, AND THE LIKE.
   The Board of Public Works and Safety or, at its direction, designated
employees of the city, is authorized to do the following:
   (A)   Designate and maintain by appropriate devices, marks, or lines upon
the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in its opinion
there is a particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway and at other
places as it may deem necessary;
   (B)   Establish safety zones of that kind and character and at those places
as it may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians;
   (C)   Mark lanes for traffic on street pavements at those places as it may
deem advisable; and
   (D)   Place markers, buttons, or signs within or adjacent to intersections
indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning at those
intersections.
(1987 Code, § 8-124) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 71.035 OBEDIENCE TO LANE MARKERS REQUIRED.
   When authorized markers, buttons, or other indications are placed within an
intersection indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning thereat,
no driver of a vehicle shall disregard or disobey the directions of these
indications.
(1987 Code, § 8-125) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.036 BOARD RESPONSIBILITY; STREET AND TRAFFIC-CONTROL SIGNS.
   (A)   Traffic-control signs. The Board of Public Works and Safety of this
city shall have the responsibility for the emplacement, displacement, and
maintenance of all traffic-control signs and insignia of any kind, character,
or description required by this title or by other ordinance of this city or by
any law of this state.
(1987 Code, § 8-126)
   (B)   Street name signs. The Board of Public Works and Safety shall have the
further responsibility for the emplacement, displacement, and maintenance of
all official signs denoting for the benefit of the public the names of all
streets or other public ways.
(1987 Code, § 8-127)
(Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 71.037 UNAUTHORIZED SIGNS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall place, maintain, or display upon or in view of any highway
any unauthorized sign, signal, marking, or device which purports to be or is an
imitation of or resembles an official traffic-control device or railroad sign
or signal, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, or which hides
from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any official traffic-control
device or any railroad sign or signal, and no person shall place or maintain
nor shall any public authority permit upon any highway, any traffic sign or
signal bearing thereon any commercial advertising. This shall not be deemed to
prohibit the erection upon private property, adjacent to highways and streets,
of signs giving useful directional information and of a type that cannot be
mistaken for official signs.
(1987 Code, § 8-130) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.038 REMOVAL OF UNAUTHORIZED SIGNS.
   Every above prohibited sign, signal, or marking is declared to be a public
nuisance and the authority having jurisdiction over the street or highway is
empowered to remove the same, or cause it to be removed without notice.
(1987 Code, § 8-131) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.039 TAMPERING WITH OFFICIAL SIGNS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall without lawful authority attempt to, or in fact alter,
deface, injure, knock down, or remove any official traffic-control device, any
railroad sign or signal, any street sign, or the post on which it may be
located, or any inscription, shield, or insignia thereon or any other part
thereof.
(1987 Code, § 8-132) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.040 VIOLATIONS; LIABILITY.
   Any person who in violation of §
71.039 above causes damage to any official traffic-control device or sign, any
railroad sign or signal, or any street sign shall be responsible in law for the
damages thereto.
(1987 Code, § 8-133) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
SCHOOL ZONES
§ 71.050 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   SCHOOL ZONE. The specific city block in which any public or parochial
elementary or junior high school building is located, and the area covered by a
further distance of one block, in each direction, from the block in which the
school building as mentioned above is located; and also the block in which any
high school is located and the area covered by a further distance of one block,
in each direction, from the block in which that high school building is
located.
(1987 Code, § 8-165) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969; Ord. 1610, passed 4-26-
1971)
§ 71.051 SPEED LIMIT.
   When the school zone is so marked by appropriate signs, it shall be unlawful
for any person to drive or operate any motor vehicle within the school zone at
a speed greater than 20 miles per hour, when children are present either on the
sidewalk adjacent to the streets in the school zone or upon or at the
crosswalks preparatory to crossing those streets.
(1987 Code, § 8-166) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.052 LOITERING RESTRICTED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, other than those excepted in §
71.053 below, to stand around or to move slowly about or to spend time idly or
to idle or linger, either on foot or in a motor vehicle, within a school zone
as hereinbefore defined during a period of time beginning one hour before
school opens and extending to a period of time one hour after school is closed
on school days or upon days when the school is open for any educational
purpose.
(1987 Code, § 8-167) (Ord. 1610, passed 4-26-1971)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.053 EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of §
71.052 above shall not apply to any of the following:
   (A)   A student at the educational institution;
   (B)   A parent, guardian, relative, or other person having custody of any
student of that educational institution present in the school zone for the
express purpose of contacting the student of which that person is a parent,
guardian, relative, or other having custody thereof; or
   (C)   Any person having a specific or legitimate reason to be within the
school zone for any lawful purpose not connected to the educational institution
itself or any student thereof.
(1987 Code, § 8-168)
§ 71.054 VIOLATIONS.
   Any person who violates any of these provisions shall be guilty of a code
violation and upon conviction that person shall be fined.
(1987 Code, § 8-169) (Ord. 1610, passed 4-26-1971)
Penalty, see § 70.99
PROCESSIONS AND PARADES
§ 71.065 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No procession or parade, containing ten or more persons, or five or more
vehicles, excepting funeral processions, forces of the U.S. Army, Navy, or Air
Force, the military forces of this state, and the forces of the city Police or
Fire Department, shall occupy, march, or proceed upon or along any street
within this city, except and until that procession or parade shall have
received a permit so to do, issued without charge by the Board of Public Works
and Safety of this city.
(1987 Code, § 8-75) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.066 WAITING PERIOD FOR APPLICATION.
   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall not unreasonably withhold a
parade or procession permit, as hereinbefore required, to any religious,
fraternal, political, or social group or organization, applying therefor in
writing, to the Board at its regular meeting at least ten days in advance of
the time of the requested permit.
(1987 Code, § 8-76) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 71.067 PARADE HOURS ESTABLISHED BY BOARD.
   In order to facilitate the movement of traffic, the Board of Public Works
and Safety, in its permit, as mentioned above, may set the hours that the
parade or procession shall be conducted, and designate specifically the streets
and the route thereof.
(1987 Code, § 8-77) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 71.068 FUNERAL PROCESSIONS; NOTIFICATION REQUIRED.
   Funeral processions shall not be required to secure a permit but shall
notify the city Police Department of the planned route, the time, destination,
and other pertinent facts, at least 24 hours in advance of the procession.
(1987 Code, § 8-78) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 71.069 FUNERAL PROCESSION DRIVING.
   Each driver in a funeral procession shall drive as near to the right-hand
edge of the roadway as practical and with the vehicle lights being turned on,
and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practical and safe.
(1987 Code, § 8-79) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 71.070 FUNERAL PROCESSION IDENTIFICATION.
   A funeral procession of vehicles shall be identified as such by the display
upon the outside of each vehicle of a pennant or other identifying insignia or
by some other method as may be provided by the director in charge thereof,
provided the insignia or pennant clearly identifies the type of the procession.
(1987 Code, § 8-80) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 71.071 DRIVING BETWEEN PROCESSION VEHICLES RESTRICTED.
   No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral
or any other authorized procession while they are in motion and when those
vehicles are conspicuously designated as required in this subchapter or are
operating under a properly issued permit. This provision shall not apply at
intersections where traffic is controlled by police officers.
(1987 Code, § 8-81) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
STOPS AND YIELDS
§ 71.085 DESIGNATED THROUGH STREETS; STOPS AND YIELDS.
   The streets set forth in
Ch. 74, Sch. II, are designated as through streets, and when so marked by
appropriate stop signs for intersecting traffic, vehicular traffic approaching
the through street from intersecting streets shall be required to stop and
yield right-of-way to vehicles upon the through street, all as defined and
required by the Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on Highways, being I.C. 9-21-1-
1 et seq., as enacted by the state and as now or hereafter amended; provided
further that at particular designated intersections along the through street
being removed from the designation by this section all as hereinafter provided
as such a through street.
(1987 Code, § 8-145) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 71.086 CROSSING ALLEYS; STOPS AND YIELDS.
   The driver of any vehicle crossing any alley shall first stop his or her
vehicle immediately prior to crossing the alley, and yield right-of-way to all
other vehicles on the intersecting alley.
(1987 Code, § 8-146) (Ord. 32, 1979, passed 11-26-1979)
§ 71.087 STOP INTERSECTIONS.
   (A)   The intersections set forth in
Ch. 74, Sch. III, Table A, are designated as four-way stop intersections, and
when so marked by appropriate signs, obedience thereto will be required by
drivers of all motor vehicles approaching those intersections from any of the
four separate directions, as established in the Uniform Act Regulating Traffic
on Highways, being I.C. 9-21-1-1 et seq., as enacted by the state and as now or
hereafter amended.
(1987 Code, § 8-147) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
   (B)   The intersections set forth in
Ch. 74, Sch. III, Table B, are designated as three-way stop intersections, and
when so marked by appropriate signs, obedience thereto will be required of all
drivers of motor vehicles approaching these intersections from any of the three
separate directions, as established in the Uniform Act, being I.C. 9-21-1-1 et
seq.
(1987 Code, § 8-148) (Ord. 30, 1976, passed 9-27-1976)
   (C)   The intersections set forth in
Ch. 74, Sch. III, Table C, are designated as two-way stop intersections, and
when so marked by appropriate signs, obedience thereto will be required of all
drivers of motor vehicles approaching these intersections from either of the
two separate directions, as established in the Uniform Act, being I.C. 9-21-1-
1 et seq.
(1987 Code, § 8-149) (Ord. 6, 1982, passed 4-26-1982)
   (D)   The intersections set forth in
Ch. 74, Sch. III, Table D, are designated as one-way stop intersections, and
when so marked by appropriate signs, obedience thereto will be required of all
drivers of motor vehicles approaching these intersections from the marked
direction, as established in the Uniform Act, being I.C. 9-21-1-1 et seq.
(1987 Code, § 8-150) (Ord. 1, 1987, passed 2-9-1987)
§ 71.088 RAILROAD CROSSINGS; REQUIRED STOPS.
   All drivers or operators of any motor vehicles shall stop their motor
vehicles prior to crossing the designated railroad crossings as set forth in
Ch. 74, Sch. III, Table E, and each of them.
(1987 Code, § 8-152)
§ 71.089 YIELD INTERSECTIONS.
   The intersections set forth in
Ch. 74, Sch. IV, are designated as yield right-of-way intersections, and when
so marked by appropriate signs, obedience thereto will be required of the
drivers of all motor vehicles approaching the intersections from the designated
directions and streets, as established in the Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on
Highways, being I.C. 9-21-1-1 et seq., as enacted by the state and as now or
hereafter amended, the yield intersections and the designation of the traffic
being required to yield being as set forth in
Ch. 74, Sch. IV.
(1987 Code, § 8-151)
ADDITIONAL DRIVING RULES
§ 71.100 SPEED LIMITS; VIOLATIONS.
   No person shall drive or operate any motor vehicle over and along the
streets in excess of the speeds as set forth in
Ch. 74, Sch. VI.
(1987 Code, §§ 8-213, 8-214) (Ord. 25, 1979, passed 8-27-1979; Ord. 26, 1984,
passed 10-8-1984)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.101 U-TURNS PROHIBITED.
   U-turns by motor vehicles shall be prohibited at all times over, along, or
upon any street or alley within the city.
(1987 Code, § 8-160) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
Cross-reference:
   Turn-restricted intersections, see
Ch. 74, Sch. V
§ 71.102 DRIVING ON SIDEWALK PROHIBITED.
   The driver of a vehicle shall not drive within any sidewalk area except at a
permanent or temporary driveway.
(1987 Code, § 8-184) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.103 BACKING VEHICLES.
   The driver of a vehicle shall not back the same unless that movement can be
made with reasonable safety and without interfering with other traffic.
(1987 Code, § 8-185) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.104 RIDING ON MOTORCYCLES.
   No person operating a motorcycle shall ride other than upon the permanent
and regular seat attached thereto, or carry any other person, nor shall any
other person ride upon the motorcycle other than upon a firmly attached seat to
the rear or side of the operator.
(1987 Code, § 8-186) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.105 ROLLER SKATES, COASTERS, AND THE LIKE PROHIBITED ON STREETS.
   (A)   No person upon roller skates or riding in or by means of any coaster,
toy vehicle, or similar device shall go upon any roadway except while crossing
a street on a crosswalk, and when so crossing that person shall be granted all
of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to
pedestrians.
   (B)   This section shall not apply upon any street while set aside as a play
street as authorized by other sections of this title.
(1987 Code, § 8-187) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.106 ATTACHING TO VEHICLES PROHIBITED.
   No person riding upon any bicycle, motorcycle, coaster, sled, roller skates,
or any toy vehicle shall attach the same or himself or herself to any moving
vehicle upon any roadway.
(1987 Code, § 8-188) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.107 HITCHING ANIMALS RESTRICTED.
   No person shall, at any time, tie or hitch any animal for any period of time
whatsoever to any street sign or traffic-control sign within the city.
(1987 Code, § 8-189) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.108 PEDESTRIAN RULES.
   (A)   Pedestrians shall be subject to all traffic-control signals.
   (B)   At all other places, pedestrians shall be granted the following rights
and be further subject to the following restrictions.
      (1)   When traffic-control signals are not in place or not in operation,
the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping
if need be to so yield, to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within a crosswalk
when the pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is
traveling, or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite
half of the roadway as to be in danger, but no pedestrian shall suddenly leave
a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle
which is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield.
      (2)   Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any
unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the
roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not
overtake and pass the stopped vehicle.
      (3)   Pedestrians shall move, whenever practicable, upon the right half
of crosswalks.
      (4)   No pedestrian shall cross a roadway at any place other than by a
route at right angles to the curb or by the shortest route to the opposite
curb, except in a crosswalk.
      (5)   Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within
a marked crosswalk, or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection, shall
yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway.
      (6)   Between adjacent intersections at which traffic-control signals are
in operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a crosswalk.
      (7)   No pedestrian shall cross a roadway other than in a crosswalk in
the congested traffic area of this city.
      (8)   Where sidewalks are not provided, any pedestrian walking along and
upon a highway shall, when practicable, walk only on the left side of the
roadway or its shoulder facing traffic which may approach from the opposite
direction.
      (9)   No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a
ride from the driver of any vehicle.
(1987 Code, § 8-158) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
STREET CLOSINGS
§ 71.120 TEMPORARY STREET CLOSINGS; POLICY.
   It is declared to be in the best interests of the public policy of this city
and the citizens thereof, and in furtherance of the public convenience,
necessity, and safety, to provide conditions under which the privilege of
parking motor vehicles over, upon, and along the public streets of this city
may be temporarily suspended, and further, the temporary closing of public
streets, or portions thereof, for prescribed purposes may be authorized.
(1987 Code, § 8-96) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 71.121 SNOW EMERGENCY; AUTHORITY AND PROCEDURES.
   (A)   Snow emergency declaration by Mayor. By authority of this subchapter
and section, the Mayor of this city be, and is, authorized to declare a snow
emergency as hereinafter defined, and further to provide in that declaration,
that during the snow emergency, the parking of motor vehicles over, upon, and
along designated streets of this city, or portions thereof, may be suspended,
and designating public streets, or portions thereof, to be temporarily closed
to all vehicular traffic.
(1987 Code, § 8-97)
   (B)   Snow emergency defined. For the purpose of this subchapter, the
following definition shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or
requires a different meaning.
      SNOW EMERGENCY. A period of time, either before, during, or after a
snowfall, when in the sound discretion of the Mayor, circumstances warrant the
determination that a snow emergency exists, which may be based upon a forecast
by the U.S. Weather Bureau that there will be a snowfall to such an extent that
vehicular traffic may be expected to be particularly hazardous or congested due
to the elements, and during which period of time the parking of motor vehicles
could hinder, delay, or obstruct the proper flow of traffic or the proper
cleaning, clearing, and removal of snow from the streets in order to make them
more safe for public travel.
(1987 Code, § 8-98)
   (C)   Notice of snow emergency through news media. Where possible, the Mayor
in declaring a snow emergency shall give advance notice thereof through all
public news media, to include both newspaper and radio, but that snow emergency
may be declared by the posting of appropriate signs over and along the streets
affected, or by the posting of guards or barricades at the entrances and exits
of the public streets so affected, without other advance public notice thereof
through the news media.
(1987 Code, § 8-99)
   (D)   Powers of Mayor during snow emergency. In declaring a snow emergency,
the Mayor of this city in his or her declaration through the news media, or by
the posting of notices, signs, guards, or barricades, as mentioned above,
within his or her sole discretion, may completely close certain public streets
or portions thereof to all vehicular traffic, and further, the Mayor, within
his or her sole discretion, may temporarily suspend the parking of motor
vehicles over, along, and upon the public streets, or portions thereof, for the
period of time necessary and during the duration of the snow emergency.
(1987 Code, § 8-100)
   (E)   Closing and opening streets. During the duration of the snow
emergency, and in the same manner as hereinbefore provided, the Mayor, at his
or her sole discretion, may reopen streets previously closed, or close streets
previously open, or change the restrictions as to the parking of motor
vehicles, all as hereinbefore provided.
(1987 Code, § 8-101)
(Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 71.122 BOARD AUTHORITY OVER STREET EVENTS.
   The Board of Public Works and Safety, or its majority, may within their
discretion, close designated streets, or portions thereof, for the purpose of
civic parades or other civic occasions of similar import, upon written request
of local and bona fide religious, fraternal, scholastic, or other civic
organizations, wholly upon those conditions as the Board, within its
discretion, finds to be proper; further, in conjunction therewith, the Board
may temporarily, for those purposes, suspend or restrict the privilege of
parking of motor vehicles over, upon, and along the designated streets, or
portions thereof, all as hereinbefore provided.
(1987 Code, § 8-102) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 71.123 CLOSING FOR EVENTS; ADVANCE NOTICE REQUIRED.
   For the purposes described in §
71.122 above, the Board of Public Works and Safety or its majority may
designate the streets, or portions thereof, to be closed, and may further
restrict or suspend the parking of motor vehicles all as in §
71.122 so stated by advance notice thereof through the public news media or by
the posting of appropriate signs, barricades, or guards along the streets, or
portion thereof so affected, as herein provided and in accord with the
requirements of §§
71.121(C) and
71.121(D) for declaration of a snow emergency by the Mayor.
(1987 Code, § 8-105) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 71.124 STREET COMMISSIONER AUTHORITY OVER MAINTENANCE.
   For the purposes of leaf removal, cleaning, or the repair, maintenance,
construction, or reconstruction of the public streets of this city, or portions
thereof, the Street Commissioner with the approval of the Mayor may close
public streets, or portions thereof, for either or any of these purposes, and
temporarily restrict or suspend the privilege of parking of motor vehicles
over, upon, or along designated public streets, or portions thereof, in order
to expedite the cleaning, repair, maintenance, construction, or reconstruction
of any public street within this city.
(1987 Code, § 8-103) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 71.125 CLOSING FOR MAINTENANCE; PROCEDURE.
   The Street Commissioner, with the approval of the Mayor, for any of the
purposes described in §
71.124 above, may designate the streets, or portions thereof, to be closed, and
may restrict or suspend the parking of motor vehicles over, upon, and along
designated public streets, or portions thereof, by the same methods designated
by §§
71.121(C) and
71.121(D) for declaration of a snow emergency by the Mayor.
(1987 Code, § 8-104) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 71.126 VIOLATIONS.
   (A)   Violations when street closed. When any street, or portion thereof, is
closed, by and through any of the means herein provided, and for any of the
purposes established herein, it shall be unlawful for the owner of, or person
in charge of, any motor vehicle to cause the same to be driven over, along, or
upon that public street, or portion thereof, or to drive around or through any
guard or barricade established in accord with the provisions of this
subchapter.
(1987 Code, § 8-106)
   (B)   Suspension of parking privileges. When the parking of motor vehicles
is restricted, or temporarily suspended, in accord with the provisions of this
subchapter and section, it shall be unlawful for the owner of, or the person in
charge of, any motor vehicle, to permit, cause, or allow the same to be parked
in any area or parking space prohibited by this subchapter and section.
(1987 Code, § 8-107)
(Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.127 REMOVAL OF VEHICLES IN VIOLATION; TOWING.
   (A)   Removal of vehicles by owner. When the owner of or person in charge of
any motor vehicle is personally advised by any agent or employee of this city
that the motor vehicle is parked in violation of this subchapter and section,
it shall be unlawful for the owner of or person in charge of that motor vehicle
so parked, to fail and refuse to immediately remove the motor vehicle from any
parking space then and there occupied in violation of this subchapter and
section.
(1987 Code, § 8-108)
   (B)   Towing vehicles. In addition to the foregoing, any police officer of
this city, upon discovering any motor vehicle parked in violation of any of the
provisions of this subchapter and section, may cause the motor vehicle to be
removed to a public garage as authorized by §
73.65 of this code.
(1987 Code, § 8-109)
(Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
BICYCLES
§ 71.130 DRIVING ON OR ACROSS SIDEWALKS; YIELDING TO BICYCLE OPERATOR ON
SIDEWALK.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any wagon, motorcycle,
motor vehicle or any animal upon, over or across any curb, sidewalk or
grassplot on any street in the city, except upon a driveway constructed over
the same, or as otherwise permitted by this Code or by a permit therefor from
the city.
   (B)   The driver or operator of any motor vehicle shall yield the right-of-
way to any bicycle operator on a sidewalk.
(Ord. 23, 2013, passed 10-28-2013)
§ 71.131 BICYCLE PATHS AND LANES.
   (A)   Bicycle paths and lanes shall be used exclusively for the operation of
bicycles unless signage specifies joint use with pedestrians.
   (B)   With the exception of a moped being operated exclusively with human
muscular power, no person shall operate any other conveyance in a designated
bicycle path or lane.
   (C)   A person may operate a motor vehicle upon a bicycle lane for the
limited purpose of making a turn, entering or leaving an alley, private road,
or driveway.
(Ord. 23, 2013, passed 10-28-2013)
§ 71.132 YIELDING TO BICYCLE OPERATOR IN BICYCLE PATH OR LANE.
   The driver or operator of any motor vehicle shall yield the right-of-way to
an individual operating a bicycle on a designated bicycle path or lane.
(Ord. 23, 2013, passed 10-28-2013)
§ 71.133 DRIVING, STANDING OR PARKING ON BICYCLE PATHS OR LANES PROHIBITED.
   (A)   The driver or operator of any motor vehicle shall not drive, unless
entering or exiting a legal parking space, or stand, or park the motor vehicle
upon any path or lane designated by official signs or markings for the use of
bicycles, or otherwise drive or place the motor vehicle in such a manner as to
impede bicycle traffic on such path or lane.
   (B)   The driver or operator of any motor vehicle shall not stand or park
the motor vehicle upon any lane designated by pavement markings for the shared
use of motor vehicles and bicycles, or place the motor vehicle in such a manner
as to impede bicycle traffic on such lane.
   (C)   A motor vehicle parked or standing in violation of this section may be
subject to immediate removal.
(Ord. 23, 2013, passed 10-28-2013)
§ 71.134 DUTY TO YIELD TO BICYCLE OPERATOR; MINIMUM PASSING DISTANCE.
   (A)   The driver or operator of a motor vehicle shall yield the right-of-way
to an individual operating a bicycle on a designated bicycle path or lane.
   (B)   The driver or operator of a motor vehicle overtaking a bicycle must
pass the bicycle at a safe distance of not less than three feet between the
motor vehicle and the bicycle.
(Ord. 23, 2013, passed 10-28-2013)
§ 71.135 FINES AND PENALTIES.
   In addition to other fines, fees and penalties, civil actions, forfeitures
and the like provided in §
10.99 of this Code, violations of §
71.131 through §
71.135 shall result in the imposition of a minimum fines of $25 for a first
violation and $50 for a second violation and $100 for a third violation. In
addition, violators will be responsible for any and all resulting towing
expenses.
(Ord. 23, 2013, passed 10-28-2013)
TRUCK REGULATIONS
§ 71.140 COMMERCIAL VEHICLE DEFINED.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   COMMERCIAL VEHICLE. Any vehicle other than a passenger car which is operated
for compensation or which is owned or operated by a private carrier for the
transportation of property of which that person is the owner or bailee when
that transportation is for the purpose of sale, lease, rent, or bailment, or in
the furtherance of any commercial enterprise.
(1987 Code, § 8-51) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-27-1969)
§ 71.141 DRIVING RESTRICTIONS ON VEHICLES OVER 5,000 POUNDS.
   Commercial or freight-carrying vehicles, either of which exceed 5,000 pounds
in declared gross weight, shall be restricted at all times to those streets and
parts of streets designated as state highways, except that these vehicles may
be operated on other streets solely for the purpose of either delivery or pick-
up of materials or merchandise, and then only by entering upon streets not
being state highways at the intersection nearest the destination of the vehicle
and proceeding thereon no further than the nearest intersection thereafter;
further, that these vehicles shall thereafter return by the nearest
intersection, to the closest adjacent street designated as a state highway.
(1987 Code, § 8-52) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Cross-reference:
   Parking and standing regulations; trucks and commercial vehicles, see §§
73.35 et seq.
§ 71.142 SEMI-TRUCK TRAFFIC RESTRICTIONS ON LOCAL ROADS.
   (A)   Definitions. For the purpose of this section, SEMI, SEMI-TRUCK or
TRUCK means a semi-trailer truck cab with a trailer.
   (B)   Restrictions. Semi-truck traffic is restricted on the following local
roads:
      (1)   From 209 N. Locust Drive, then south on Locust Drive to Schleter
Road.
   (C)   Exemptions. The semi-truck restrictions prescribed in this section
shall not apply to road repair, construction or maintenance vehicles while
involved in the repair, construction or maintenance of infrastructure.
   (D)   Signs. The Department of Public Works shall post appropriate signs and
markings on the above described public street(s) clearly indicating the
prohibition of semi-trucks. All such signs shall conform to the manual and
specifications for a uniform system of traffic control devices as used by the
Indiana Department of Highways. Additional signs may be installed at other
locations to properly identify local truck routes.
(Ord. 8, 2020, passed 5-11-2020)
TRAIN REGULATIONS
§ 71.155 OBSTRUCTION OF CROSSINGS RESTRICTED.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person in charge of any railroad train to
direct the operation thereof, or to so operate the same in a manner so as to
prevent the use of any street, sidewalk, or vehicle crossing within this city
for the purpose of travel thereon for a period of time longer than ten minutes,
except that this provision shall not apply to trains or cars in motion other
than those engaged in switching.
(1987 Code, § 8-176)
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person having charge of a train or
locomotive to permit that locomotive, train, or the cars thereof to remain upon
the street, alley, or sidewalk crossing for a longer period of time than ten
minutes.
(1987 Code, § 6-133)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.156 DANGEROUS CARGO; STORAGE RESTRICTED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person in charge of any railroad train to cause
any railroad car loaded with explosives of any kind or character to remain on a
siding within this city overnight without prior advance notice thereof to the
city Police Department.
(1987 Code, § 8-177) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.157 BOARDING TRAINS RESTRICTED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to get on or off, jump on or off, or
attempt to get on or off, any locomotive or any railroad car or cars while
those locomotives or cars are within the limits of this city, whether the cars
are in motion or standing still, excepting persons who are passengers getting
on or off those trains, while the trains are stopped for that purpose, and
further excepting railroad employees engaged in the performance of their
required duties.
(1987 Code, § 8-178)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.158 UNNECESSARY WHISTLE SOUNDING RESTRICTED.
   (A)   Whistles shall be sounded pursuant to applicable state law and shall
never be sounded unnecessarily.
   (B)   Conductors and other individuals violating this section shall be fined
and subject to the provisions as specifically referenced in §
10.99.
(1987 Code, § 6-131)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 71.159 WARNING DEVICES REQUIRED AT CROSSINGS.
   All railroad crossings within the city shall have adequate warning devices
installed and maintained by the railroad companies.
(1987 Code, § 6-132)
CHAPTER 72: FREEMAN FIELD REGULATIONS
Section
   
72.01   State law adopted

§ 72.01 STATE LAW ADOPTED.
   The Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on Highways, being I.C. 9-21-1-1 et seq.,
as heretofore adopted by the General Assembly of the state, and as now or
hereafter amended, is declared to be the basic traffic code in and for Freeman
Field, and all drivers, operators, or owners of any motor vehicles and all
pedestrians, where applicable, shall obey the provisions thereof, the same as
if each and every provision of the Uniform Act, being I.C. 9-21-1-1 et seq., as
aforementioned, were incorporated in detail in these regulations, it being
intended that the following provisions of these regulations shall only
implement the Uniform Act, being I.C. 9-21-1-1 et seq.
(1987 Code, § 8-204) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 72.02 SPEED LIMITS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any motor vehicle
over, on, or upon any highway, street, alley, or other traffic way in Freeman
Field at a speed greater than that which is so posted, and in no case shall any
motor vehicle be operated at a speed greater than 35 miles per hour.
(1987 Code, § 8-205) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 72.03 STOP INTERSECTIONS.
   (A)   The following intersections are designated as stop intersections, and
when so marked by appropriate signs, obedience thereto will be required of all
drivers of all motor vehicles approaching these intersections from the
designated streets or avenues, all as established by the Uniform Act Regulating
Traffic on Highways, being I.C. 9-21-1-1 et seq., as now or hereafter amended.
   (B)   The stop intersections and the designation of traffic being required
to so stop are as follows:
      (1)   All highways or streets as they intersect the railroad where stop
signs are so posted and maintained; and
      (2)   Intersections as set forth in
Ch. 74, Sch. III, Table F.
(1987 Code, § 8-206) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 72.04 YIELD INTERSECTIONS.
   The intersections set forth in
Ch. 74, Sch. IV, Table B, are designated as yield right-of-way intersections,
and when so marked by appropriate signs, obedience thereto will be required of
the drivers of all motor vehicles approaching the intersections from the
designated streets, all as established in the Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on
Highways, being I.C. 9-21-1-1 et seq., as now or hereafter amended, the yield
right-of-way intersections, and the designation of traffic being required to so
yield, being as set forth in
Ch. 74, Sch. IV, Table B.
(1987 Code, § 8-207) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 72.05 DIRECTIONAL ARROWS; TRAFFIC ISLANDS.
   (A)   Directional arrows. At the intersections designated in
Ch. 74, Sch. V, Table C, traffic shall be required to obey the directional
arrows, directing traffic to proceed either to the right or to the left, all as
the directional arrows are so posted and maintained.
(1987 Code, § 8-208)
   (B)   Traffic islands. Where certain traffic islands are now emplaced, as
set forth in
Ch. 74, Sch. V, Table C, traffic shall be required to obey the directional
arrows and move only to the right of the islands, all as the directional arrows
are so posted and maintained.
(1987 Code, § 8-209)
(Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 72.06 VIOLATIONS.
   Violations of any of the provisions of these regulations shall constitute an
infraction and upon conviction shall be punished as prescribed by Ch. 190, Acts
of 1945, state General Assembly, as amended.
(1987 Code, § 8-210) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99

GENERAL PARKING RESTRICTIONS
§ 73.01 STREET PARKING REGULATIONS.
   The following shall be the general provisions regulating the parking of
motor vehicles within the city, as follows.
   (A)   Parking on paved streets with curbs.
      (1)   On streets open for two-way traffic, and not marked for angle
parking, motor vehicles shall be parked wholly upon the surface of the street
itself, with the right-hand wheels of the vehicle parallel with, and within 12
inches of, the right-hand curb.
      (2)   On streets designated for one-way traffic, vehicles may be parked
on either side of the street, with the front wheels of the vehicle parallel
with, and within 12 inches of, the curb, with parked vehicles being headed only
in the direction of authorized traffic on that one-way street.
   (B)   Parking on paved streets without curbs.
      (1)   On streets open for two-way traffic, and not marked for angle
parking, motor vehicles shall be parked wholly off the paved portion thereof,
and solely upon the earthen berm, provided that, if there is not any earthen
berm adjacent to the paved portion of the street, then and in that event,
vehicles shall not be parked upon any grass plot adjacent to the paved portion
of these streets.
      (2)   On streets designated for one-way traffic, vehicles shall be parked
in accordance with the provisions of division (B)(1) above, except vehicles may
be parked on either side of the street as long as the vehicles are headed, when
parked, in the direction only of authorized traffic on that one-way street.
   (C)   Painted space lines. Where painted lines are used to designate parking
spaces, whether for parallel or angle parking, all vehicles shall be parked
wholly within a single parking space and shall not be parked in more than one
parking space.
   (D)   Alleys. No motor vehicles shall be parked, or permitted to remain
standing, in, over, or upon any alley within the city, excepting only
temporarily while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or
freight, with the standing, stopping, or parking to be limited to the time
necessary only to accomplish those purposes.
   (E)   Time limit. No vehicle shall be parked, or left standing, over, along,
or upon any public street within this city for a period in excess of 24 hours,
excepting that this prohibition shall not apply to the parking of a passenger
motor vehicle, by the owner thereof, in front of his or her own residence, and
further provided that this residence is located outside of the congested area
as hereinafter defined.
   (F)   Lift stations. No vehicle shall be parked or left standing over, in
front of, along, or upon any lift station or facilities associated with a lift
station within the city. The city shall erect signage designating such areas as
“no parking zones.”
(1987 Code, § 8-13) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969; Am. Ord. 27, 2020, passed
10-12- 2020) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 73.02 ADDITIONAL RESTRICTIONS POSTED.
   (A)   The Board of Public Works and Safety of the city, by proper
resolution, duly entered of record, and after notice by publication thereof,
may further restrict parking, in the following instances, or any of them:
      (1)   Upon any street when the width of the paved roadway does not exceed
20 feet, or upon one side of a street when the width of the paved roadway does
not exceed 30 feet;
      (2)   Upon the left-hand side of any one-way street; or
      (3)   Upon the side of any street adjacent to any school building when
that parking would, in its opinion, either interfere with traffic or create a
hazardous situation.
   (B)   In any situation that, in the opinion of the Board, is an emergency,
such as, but not limited to, construction or reconstruction of a portion of a
street, the Board may limit or prohibit parking, without notice thereof by
publication, by posting signs indicating that limitation or prohibition.
   (C)   When official signs prohibiting or limiting parking are so erected as
authorized above, no person shall park any vehicle upon any posted street, or
portion thereof, in violation of any official sign.
(1987 Code, § 8-14) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 73.03 PARKING PROHIBITED IN DESIGNATED AREAS.
   (A)   In addition to the prohibited areas for parking, as set out by the
Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on Highways, being I.C. 9-21-1-1 et seq., as
amended, the areas set forth in
Ch. 75, Sch. I, shall be designated as prohibited areas for the parking of
motor vehicles within the city.
(Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
   (B)   Parking shall be prohibited at any other place, where either official
signs or official markings on the painted surface of the street, prohibit
standing or parking.
(Ord. 25, 1984, passed 10-8-1984)
(1987 Code, § 8-16)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 73.04 PARKING RESTRICTIONS IN DOWNTOWN AREA.
   (A)   A vehicle shall not be parked in the public ways of the downtown area,
as designated, of the city for a period in excess of two hours.
   (B)   Residential parking will be permitted in the downtown area on Monday
through Friday from 5:00 p.m. to 9:00 a.m. and all day on Saturdays and
Sundays.
   (C)   The fine for violating this section shall be $10.
(Ord. 15, 1987, passed 4-27-1987; Am. Ord. 10, 1993, passed 4-20-1993; Am. Ord.
22, 2020, passed 10-12-2020)
(1987 Code, § 8-12)
§ 73.05 PARKING FOR STORAGE, SALE, OR MAINTENANCE PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person shall park any motor vehicle, motorcycle, truck trailer,
semi-trailer, tractor, farm tractor, bus, school bus, house car, or special
farm machinery on any street, alley, roadway, or highway for any of the
following purposes:
      (1)   Displaying the vehicle for sale, trade, exchange, or storage; or
      (2)   Washing, greasing, or repairing the vehicle, except for repairs
necessitated by breakdown, accident, or other emergency to the extent necessary
to remove the vehicle from the street, alley, roadway, or highway.
   (B)   For the purpose of this section, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      STORAGE. Parking of new or used motor vehicles on public streets, alleys,
roadways, or highways by used or new motor vehicle dealers or garage owners or
operators.
(1987 Code, § 8-56) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
CITY PARKING LOTS
§ 73.15 REGULATIONS; HOURS.
   (A)   All municipal parking lots of the city shall be open for free parking
24 hours a day, Monday through Sunday.
      (1)   A vehicle left in a city parking lot without being moved for 72
hours shall be considered an abandoned vehicle and addressed by the city in
accordance with
Ch. 93 of this code.
      (2)   Section
130.19 of this code is still in full force and effect and shall be enforced
regarding loitering in city parking lots.
   (B)   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall cause signs to be posted at
or near all entrances to the lot indicating the regulations for city parking
lots.
   (C)   Permanent residents of any C-4 zoning district, as that area is
defined in
Ch. 157 of this code, may park in city parking lots at any time, and may
ingress and egress from those lots at any time without penalty.
   (D)   Any person found in violation of any provision of this section shall
be fined.
   (E)   Criminal prosecution for trespass will be sought against any
individual with multiple violations of this section.
(1987 Code, § 8-28) (Ord. 41, 1998, passed 8-24-1998; Am. Ord. 22, 2020, passed
10-12- 2020) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 73.16 APPLICATION.
   The provisions of this subchapter shall apply, and be effective, to any and
all municipal parking lots, as now established and operating, or as hereafter
may be established and operated within the city.
(1987 Code, § 8-30) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 73.17 SPECIAL USE RESTRICTIONS; AIRCRAFT PROHIBITED.
   It shall be the policy of the city that municipal parking lots shall be used
exclusively for the parking of prescribed motor vehicles, as hereinafter
provided, excepting that upon application, the Board of Public Works and Safety
of this city, may, at its discretion and upon conditions it prescribes,
authorize any municipal parking lot, or portion thereof, to be used for a
special civic purpose for a fixed temporary period, provided further, however,
in no event shall aircraft, helicopters, and the like be permitted to land upon
city parking lots.
(1987 Code, § 8-31) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 73.18 LIABILITY DISCLAIMER.
   The city does not assume liability for any accidents occurring in and upon
the municipal parking lots, or for any thefts of vehicles or contents of
vehicles, while parked upon those premises; and further, it shall be the
responsibility of the Board of Public Works and Safety to post prominently
notices thereof on the city lots so that all persons utilizing these lots may
be so informed.
(1987 Code, § 8-32) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 73.19 SPEED LIMIT.
   No person shall operate any motor vehicle while upon any municipal parking
lot, or while entering or leaving the parking lot, at a speed greater than ten
miles per hour.
(1987 Code, § 8-33) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 73.20 ENTRY AND EXIT; YIELD RIGHT-OF- WAY.
   (A)   Yielding to pedestrians. The driver of any motor vehicle, before
entering or leaving a municipal parking lot, shall first stop and yield right-
of-way to any pedestrian upon any crosswalk or sidewalk adjacent thereto.
(1987 Code, § 8-34)
   (B)   Yielding to traffic. The driver of a motor vehicle intending to enter
a parking lot, or intending to leave a parking lot and enter upon any adjacent
street or highway, shall yield right-of-way to any other motor vehicle
approaching over and along any adjacent street or highway, which is so close to
the entrance or exit as to constitute an immediate hazard.
(1987 Code, § 8-35)
(Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 73.21 PARK WITHIN DESIGNATED SPACE.
   No person driving, or in charge of, any motor vehicle, shall permit it to be
parked, or left standing, at any time, within and upon any municipal parking
lot, at any location, except wholly within a marked or designated parking
space.
(1987 Code, § 8-37) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 73.22 VEHICLES TO BE LOCKED.
   No person driving, or in charge of, a motor vehicle shall permit it to
stand, unattended, within a city lot without first stopping the engine, locking
the ignition, and removing the key thereto.
(1987 Code, § 8-38) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 73.23 PARKING TIME LIMITS.
   No person driving or in charge of any motor vehicle shall permit that motor
vehicle to be parked or left standing in a city parking lot for any period in
excess of 72 hours.
(1987 Code, § 8-39) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969; Am. Ord. 22, 2020, passed
10-12- 2020) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 73.24 DRIVER RESPONSIBILITY; LAWS APPLY.
   No person shall, at any time, while upon a municipal parking lot, or while
entering or leaving the parking lot, drive any motor vehicle with reckless
disregard for the safety, property, or rights of others, including pedestrians
on, upon, or adjacent to the parking lot, or in any other manner in violation
of any other chapter, subchapter, or section of this city code or statute of
the state, defining and regulating the operation of motor vehicles within the
city and the state.
(1987 Code, § 8-40) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 73.25 VEHICLE IN VIOLATION; POLICE AUTHORITY TO REMOVE.
   Whenever any police officer of the city finds any motor vehicle standing
upon a municipal parking lot in violation of any of the provisions of any
chapter, subchapter, or section of this code, that officer is authorized to
require the driver or other person in charge of the motor vehicle to move the
same, or the police officer may cause and require the removal of the illegally
parked motor vehicle, as authorized by §
73.65 of this code.
(1987 Code, § 8-41) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
NON-PASSENGER AND COMMERCIAL VEHICLES
§ 73.35 RESTRICTIONS FOR VEHICLES OTHER THAN PASSENGER VEHICLES.
   No person driving any truck tractor, farm tractor, road truck, other than a
pick-up or panel truck, or any bus, school bus, or any other type of motor
vehicle other than that which is commonly defined as a passenger vehicle (the
definition to be that included in the Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on
Highways, being I.C. 9-21-1-1 et seq.) shall stop, stand, or park, or cause to
stop, stand, or park, any of these vehicles within any municipal parking lot,
excepting as set forth in
Ch. 75, Sch. VI, Table C.
(1987 Code, § 8-36)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 73.36 COMMERCIAL VEHICLE DEFINED.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   COMMERCIAL VEHICLE. As defined in §
71.140 of this code.
(1987 Code, § 8-51) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-27-1969)
§ 73.37 RESTRICTIONS ON VEHICLES OVER 5,000 POUNDS.
   Commercial and freight-carrying vehicles, either of which exceed 5,000
pounds in declared gross weight, or pulling vehicles, shall not be parked
overnight upon any public street or other public way in this city, provided
that these vehicles may park where flat parking is permitted in the residential
districts for a period of not more than one hour in duration.
(1987 Code, § 8-53) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 73.38 PARKING IN CONGESTED AREAS PROHIBITED.
   All commercial vehicles, as previously defined, all freight-carrying
vehicles, excepting only panel and pick-up trucks, and all truck trailers,
semi-trailers, tractors, buses, school buses, house cars, or special farm
machinery shall not be parked, at any time, within the congested area as
hereinafter defined, except while actually loading or discharging freight or
merchandise.
(1987 Code, § 8-54) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 73.39 UNATTENDED TANK TRUCKS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   Tank trucks and other vehicles carrying flammables, shall not be left
unattended, either in being parked or being permitted to remain standing, on
any public street or thoroughfare within this city.
   (B)   Further, while loading or discharging flammables, the driver, or his
or her assistant, shall remain in attendance with the vehicle, and the
attendant thereof shall have with him or her in his or her immediate
possession, fire extinguishers of the proper type to restrict fires by liquids
or solids contained in that vehicle, being loaded or unloaded.
(1987 Code, § 8-55) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
HANDICAPPED PARKING
§ 73.50 DESIGNATION OF HANDICAPPED SPACES.
   (A)   The City Council may designate certain parking spaces within the city
as reserved or restricted for the handicapped, and when spaces are so reserved
or restricted, by a resolution of the Council duly entered of record, and when
official signs are so erected, indicating those restrictions or reservation, no
persons other than the handicapped, shall park any vehicle in that space, or
those spaces, in violation of the official sign designating the reserved or
restricted area.
(1987 Code, § 8-19) (Ord. 8, 1978, passed 3-27-1978)
   (B)   The parking spaces set forth in
Ch. 75, Sch. III, shall be designated as prohibited parking areas for all
vehicles except those specifically marked by appropriate licensing as for
handicapped persons. It shall be unlawful for any person to park, or permit to
remain standing, any motor vehicle at these locations unless that vehicle is
designated as licensed for a handicapped person.
(1987 Code, § 8-20) (Ord. 18, 1989, passed 8-14-1989)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 73.51 APPLICATION PROCEDURE.
   (A)   Any person who requires a handicapped parking space may apply to the
Board of Public Works and Safety on an application issued by the Board.
   (B)   The application shall be delivered to the office of the Mayor of the
city. Each application must be submitted annually and will be deemed invalid
one year from date of approval by the Board.
   (C)   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall, at a regularly scheduled
meeting, review the application for handicapped parking space.
      (1)   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall approve or deny the
request after review of:
         (a)   The application;
         (b)   The need of the applicant; and
         (c)   The parking space requested by the Director of Public Works or
his or her agent.
      (2)   The Board may also impose its own terms and conditions on the
granting of a handicapped parking space. Violation of those terms may result in
the revocation of the grant of a handicapped parking space.
   (D)   In the event that the Board of Public Works and Safety denies the
request of the applicant for a handicapped parking space, the applicant may
appeal the decision to the City Council.
(1987 Code, § 2-20) (Ord. 51, 1992, passed 1-11-1993)
ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
§ 73.65 TOWING; OFFENDER RESPONSIBLE FOR CHARGES.
   In addition to other penalties as may be herein provided for the violation
of the parking regulations of this city code, whenever any police officer of
the city finds any motor vehicle to be improperly parked, that officer is
authorized to require the driver or operator thereof, if available, to move the
same, and whenever a police officer finds any unattended motor vehicle
improperly parked and in violation of any provision of this code, as
hereinbefore or hereinafter set out, or whenever any parked motor vehicle is
constituting an obstruction to traffic or the use of the public streets by
other members of the public generally, the police officer is authorized to
provide for the removal of that vehicle to a convenient garage or other place
of parking, provided further that any towing charge or storage charge
occasioned thereby shall be the responsibility of, and borne by, the offender
or the owner of that motor vehicle.
(1987 Code, § 8-15) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
Penalty, see § 70.99
§ 73.66 DETERMINING PARKING VIOLATIONS; PROCEDURES.
   The procedures for regulating the parking of vehicles and determining
overtime parking may include the following.
   (A)   The city Police Department is authorized to determine the method or
methods by which the parking attendant is allowed to determine parking
violations.
(Ord. 9, 1993, passed 4-26-1993)
   (B)   In the event a member of, or civil employee of, the city Police
Department determines that a vehicle has been parked overtime, it shall then be
the duty of that member or civil employee, as aforementioned, to ticket that
vehicle, which ticket shall include, but not necessarily be limited to, the
following:
      (1)   A designation of, or location of, the alleged overtime parking;
      (2)   The state license number of the vehicle;
      (3)   The date and hour of the alleged offense; and
      (4)   The specific section of this code the owner or operator is charged
with violating, and the specific form of the ticket to be as prescribed by the
Chief of Police, but to be different than the state Uniform Traffic Ticket.
(Ord. 15, 1987, passed 4-27-1987)
   (C)   In the event that three citations are issued to the registered owner
of a motor vehicle and remain unpaid for a period of 30 days, the Clerk-
Treasurer of the city shall forward a written notice to the registered owner of
the vehicle or vehicles that:
      (1)   If the assessed fines are not paid within 14 days from the date of
the Clerk-Treasurer’s written notice, the citations shall be forwarded to the
City Attorney for prosecution; and
      (2)   In the event that the registered owner fails to pay those citations
within 14 days of notice, the City Attorney may initiate legal proceedings in
the appropriate court for collection of the unpaid fine or fines. The violator
shall also be liable for court costs as prescribed by the County Clerk.
   (D)   (1)   The provisions of
Ch. 75, Sch. II, Table C, regarding two-hour parking, only apply to vehicles
parked or standing on the streets of the city in the specifically designated
areas during the periods of time set forth as follows: on Monday through Friday
of each week, between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m.
(Ord. 32, 1988, passed 12-12-1988)
      (2)   With regard to the provisions of
Ch. 75, Sch. II, Table C, regarding two-hour parking, all parking shall be
designated by markings.
   (E)   The parking attendant is authorized to issue parking citations for any
parking violation, including but not limited to violations of any handicap,
fire hydrant, alleyway, and time limit regulations.
   (F)   In the event that three citations are issued to the registered owner
of a motor vehicle and remain unpaid for a period of 30 days, the Clerk-
Treasurer of the city shall forward a written notice of the unpaid citations to
the Bureau of Motor Vehicles to be attached to the owner’s driver’s license.
    (G)   The Clerk-Treasurer of the city is authorized to void tickets for
persons who have exceeded the two-hour limitation while receiving services from
downtown professional businesses. The ticket must be signed by the professional
service providing the service. Matters of disability will be given serious
consideration.
(Ord. 9, 1993, passed 4-26-1993)
(1987 Code, § 8-25)
Penalty, see § 70.99
