POTENTIALLY DAMAGING STREET USAGE
§ 94.01 VEHICLES REQUIRING PERMIT.
   Before any person shall use any street, alley, or other public way, or any
portion thereof, for any of the following purposes, that person shall first
secure a permit so to do from the City Clerk-Treasurer, to be issued only upon
the approval of the application therefor by the Board of Public Works and
Safety of this city:
   (A)   The movement of any heavy machinery;
   (B)   The movement of any vehicle not equipped with pneumatic tires; or
   (C)   Any vehicle or combination of vehicles with a gross weight in excess
of 72,000 pounds.
(1987 Code, § 8-113) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 94.02 MOVING BUILDING; PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Before any person shall use any street, alley, or any other public way or
any portion thereof for the purpose of removing or moving any house, building,
or other structure, that person shall first secure a permit so to do from the
City Clerk-Treasurer, to be issued only upon the approval of the application
therefor, by the Board of Public Works and Safety.
(1987 Code, § 8-114) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 94.03 STORAGE OF CONSTRUCTION MATERIAL ON STREET; PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Before any person shall be permitted to use any street, sidewalk, alley, or
other public way or any portion thereof for the storage of supplies or material
to be used in the construction, renovation, repair, or the tearing down of any
building or structure, or any improvement of any type whatsoever, that person
shall first secure a permit so to do from the City Clerk- Treasurer, to be
issued only upon the approval of the application therefor by the Board of
Public Works and Safety of this city.
(1987 Code, § 8-115) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 94.04 PERMIT APPLICATION FORMS.
   Applications for the permits in all of the above instances shall be on forms
as prescribed by the Board, and applicants shall furnish details thereon as the
Board may require.
(1987 Code, § 8-116) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 94.05 PERMIT CONDITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   In the issuance thereof, the Board may designate or otherwise limit
specifically the street, sidewalk, alley, or other public way or portion
thereof that may be so used, and for the periods of time the street, sidewalk,
alley, or other public way may be so used for the purposes as described in the
permit.
(1987 Code, § 8-117)
   (B)   In the issuance of permits as described above, the Board may further
require as a condition precedent thereof that this use of the street, alley,
sidewalk, curb, gutter, or other public way shall not interfere with the flow
of any surface water or totally interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic.
(1987 Code, § 8-119)
(Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 94.06 BOND.
   The Board, as a further condition of the issuance of permits as described
above, may require the applicant to post an indemnifying bond payable to the
city in an amount and with that surety as the Board may deem proper and
reasonable, the terms and conditions of the bond to protect and indemnify the
city against damage to any of its public improvements.
(1987 Code, § 8-118) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 94.07 PERMIT FEES.
   The Board, at its option and by its regulation duly adopted in advance of
the application therefor, may prescribe the license fees to be charged for the
issuance of all permits as described above, the license charge therefor not to
be in excess of the amount given in Ch. 36 of this code for any single permit.
(1987 Code, § 8-120) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
§ 94.08 COORDINATION WITH CITY DEPARTMENTS.
   Persons securing permits before utilizing the same shall coordinate in
advance the use of any street, alley, or other public way, with both the Police
Department and the Fire Department of the city, and all concerned public
utilities, to include the city Sanitation Department.
(1987 Code, § 8-121) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
OBSTRUCTION OF PUBLIC WAYS
§ 94.20 OBSTRUCTIONS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct by any means, including but
not limited to the storage of trash, litter, or other disposable debris, the
free passage and movement of pedestrians or vehicles upon any street, sidewalk,
alley, or any other public way or any portion thereof at any time, unless the
obstruction as described above is in response to other specific authority so to
do in accord with other provisions of this chapter, the traffic code in Title
VII of this code, or other sections of this code.
(1987 Code, § 8-136) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969) Penalty, see §
10.99
Statutory reference:
   Disorderly conduct, see I.C. 35-45-1-3
§ 94.21 FIRES PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to build, cause to be built, place, or
cause to be placed any fire at any time upon any street, sidewalk, alley, or
other public way or any portion thereof, whether that street, sidewalk, alley,
or other public way or portion thereof be paved or not.
(1987 Code, § 8-137) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 94.22 RESPONSIBILITY FOR DAMAGES.
   Any person causing damage to any sidewalk, curb, gutter, street, alley, or
any other public way of any type shall be held responsible in law therefor
irrespective of whether the use thereof was lawful or unlawful, and without
further regard to whether the use thereof was in accord with a permit duly
issued as herein provided.
(1987 Code, § 8-138) (Ord. 1556, passed 11-24-1969)
EXCAVATIONS AND CONSTRUCTION
§ 94.35 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation, not under general
or special contract with the city, or not being a regular employee of the city,
to cut, dig, excavate, remove, repair, renovate, or replace, any street, alley,
sidewalk, curb, or gutter, or to do or perform any work or labor that disturbs
the surface of any public easement or other public way, or of any other type of
public improvement, or portion or part thereof, without first securing a permit
so to do, as hereinafter provided.
(1987 Code, § 7-17) (Ord. 1581, passed 12-22-1969) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 94.36 SCOPE.
   Any and all work within the street, alley, any public easement or other
public way, or the right-of- way thereof, or that which affects the surface
thereof or the surface of any sidewalk, curb, gutter, or other public
improvement, including but not limited to the following, i.e., forcing a pipe
or other conduit under the surface, trenches between the sidewalk or curb, or
trenches outside the actual surface thereof, but within the right-of-way
containing the improvements, shall be covered by this subchapter and require
that a permit be first secured before the work is begun.
(1987 Code, § 7-18) (Ord. 1581, passed 12-22-1969)
§ 94.37 FIFTEEN-DAY ADVANCE APPLICATION.
   These permits shall be secured at least fifteen days in advance of their
intended use, unless an emergency therefor exists, in which event a permit may
be issued on a lesser interval when the emergency is so justified to the
issuing authority.
(1987 Code, § 7-19) (Ord. 1581, passed 12-22-1969; Am. Ord. 30, 2021, passed 8-
23-2021)
§ 94.38 PERMIT FEES.
    Permits may be issued, on proper application, by the City Clerk-Treasurer,
or their designee, upon approval thereof by the Board of Public Works and
Safety (hereinafter referred to as the “Board”), and subject to further
compliance by the permittee with subsequent sections of this subchapter, on
payment of a fee as set forth in
Ch. 36 of this code for regular permits or emergency permits.
(1987 Code, § 7-20) (Ord. 1581, passed 12-22-1969; Am. Ord. 30, 2021, passed 8-
23-2021)
§ 94.39 REPAIR COSTS.
   In the event a permit is required for any cutting, digging, excavating,
removing, repairing, renovating, or replacing any sidewalk, curb, gutter,
street, alley, or any public easement or other public way, that is paved with
any type of permanent surface material, the application shall also include the
tender of the cost of the repairs thereof, the charge therefor to be determined
by using, where applicable, the same schedule of fees as established for the
state Highway Commission in determining its street repair charges.
(1987 Code, § 7-21) (Ord. 1581, passed 12-22-1969)
§ 94.40 BACKFILLING; RESTORATION.
   No additional or further charge other than the permit fee shall be required
for any cut or excavation in any unimproved street, alley, or public easement,
provided, however, that the applicant shall be required to backfill the trench
or opening therein with the same material as that of the street, alley, or
public easement itself, by filling and tamping the refilled trench thoroughly
and maintaining its surface, which has been disturbed, in a smooth and uniform
condition for a period of four weeks after traffic is permitted to pass over
the filled trench or opening. Backfilling the opening with well-graded gravel
shall remove the requirement of tamping.
(1987 Code, § 7-22) (Ord. 1581, passed 12-22-1969)
§ 94.41 BARRICADES AND LIGHTS.
   All holders of permits, issued as described above, shall further be required
to post, keep, and maintain any and all necessary barricades, detour or other
warning signs, including appropriate signals, flashing lights, or other
illumination, to protect either vehicular or pedestrian traffic affected by the
work being performed under the permit.
(1987 Code, § 7-23) (Ord. 1581, passed 12-22-1969)
§ 94.42 PERMIT CONDITIONS.
   (A)   Restriction on blocking rights-of-way. As a condition precedent to the
issuance of this type of permit, the Board, in its approval of the application,
may specifically provide that the entire street, sidewalk, alley, or other
public way, including easement, shall not be totally blocked at one time, and
the Board may further specify for what period of time or under what limitations
the blocking of the streets, sidewalks, alleys, or other public ways, may be
authorized under the permit.
(1987 Code, § 7-24)
   (B)   Restriction on flow interference. As a further condition precedent to
the issuance of the permit, in its approval of the application, the Board may
provide that the work, construction, or repair will not interfere with the
proper flow of surface water, and further provide that pedestrian and vehicular
traffic shall be maintained.
(1987 Code, § 7-25)
(Ord. 1581, passed 12-22-1969)
§ 94.43 COORDINATION WITH CITY DEPARTMENTS.
   Persons securing permits, as mentioned above, before utilizing the same,
shall be required to coordinate, in advance, with the city Police Department,
the city Fire Department, and all concerned public utilities, to include the
city Sanitation Department.
(1987 Code, § 7-26) (Ord. 1581, passed 12-22-1969)
§ 94.44 PERMIT ISSUANCE; GUARANTEES REQUIRED.
   As a condition precedent to the issuance of the permits detailed herein, the
applicant, by the application, warrants as follows:
   (A)   Permanent repairs will be effected within a maximum of 30 days after
the surface of the street, alley, sidewalk, curb, gutter, or any other public
way or easement is first cut or removed, unless extended, for an additional 30
days, by the Board of Public Works and Safety, upon application in writing by
the permit holder;
   (B)   The permanent repairs shall include using the same materials as are
used in the remainder of the surface, that is to say, if the surface is of
concrete, then repairs shall be of concrete, and further, if the sub-surface is
of one material, for example, concrete, and the outer surface is of another,
such as blacktop, then and in that event, by the requirements of the permit,
the required repairs shall include in that instance both a concrete sub-surface
and a blacktop outer surface;
   (C)   When the permit holder has completed the repairs, notice thereof shall
be reported to the Board of Public Works and Safety of the city, so that the
repairs may be inspected by employees of the city, under the Board’s direction;
and
   (D)   All repairs, when completed by the permit holder himself or herself,
shall be subject to the requirements of a bond, as detailed in §
94.46 of this code.
(1987 Code, § 7-27) (Ord. 1581, passed 12-22-1969)
§ 94.45 PERMIT CANCELLATION.
   Upon failure to comply with any of the requirements of §§
94.40 -
94.42, permits may be automatically canceled and voided and the persons
receiving or holding those permits may be punished as hereinafter provided.
(1987 Code, § 7-28) (Ord. 1581, passed 12-22-1969) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 94.46 INSURANCE; BOND.
   As an additional condition precedent to the issuance of these permits, the
Board may require the filing of proof of liability insurance on behalf of the
applicant, or in the event the applicant does not carry this insurance, the
Board may require a bond, in the sum as the Board finds appropriate, under the
circumstances, having regard to the work to be performed, with surety to be
approved by the Board of Public Works and Safety, to indemnify the city against
any loss arising because of the injury or damage to any person or property due
to the negligence or fault of the permit holder or his or her agents, in the
work being performed under the permit, provided that, in lieu of individual
bonds, persons, firms, or corporations regularly engaged in this work may post
an annual bond, of the same terms, with the City Clerk-Treasurer.
(1987 Code, § 7-29) (Ord. 1581, passed 12-22-1969)
§ 94.47 PERFORMANCE BONDS.
   In the event any firm, person, or corporation, generally engaged in this
type of work within the city, prefers to make the required repairs to streets
and the like with its own labor forces, that person, firm, or corporation may,
in lieu of making a deposit for street repairs as hereinbefore required, with
the approval of the Board of Public Works and Safety, post and keep a
performance bond in the office of the City Clerk- Treasurer, which performance
bond shall be in an amount, as fixed by the Board of Public Works and Safety,
equal to the estimated cost of repairs to be made by that person, firm, or
corporation for one calendar year beginning at the time of the application. In
addition thereto, this performance bond shall cover a two-year period and
guarantee, first, that the repairs will be made and perform satisfactorily for
a period of one year, and second, that the bond shall remain in effect for an
additional period of at least one year after date of last repairs.
(1987 Code, § 7-30) (Ord. 1581, passed 12-22-1969)
§ 94.48 POSTING OF PERMIT REQUIRED.
   All permits issued under this subchapter shall be posted conspicuously by
the holder thereof, at the place where the work authorized by the permit is
being performed.
(1987 Code, § 7-31) (Ord. 1581, passed 12-22-1969)
§ 94.49 VIOLATIONS.
   The violation of any provision of this subchapter shall constitute a code
violation, and, upon conviction thereof, violators may be fined, with each day
of continuing violation to constitute a separate offense.
(1987 Code, § 7-32) (Ord. 1581, passed 12-22-1969) Penalty, see §
10.99
STREET NAMES
§ 94.60 NAMING NEW STREETS.
   New streets shall be assigned names in accordance with the following:
   (A)   Plan Commission. Proposed street names shall be referred to the Plan
Commission for review and recommendation.
   (B)   Building Commissioner. Proposed street names shall also be referred to
the Building Commissioner for final determination to ensure no duplication of
names and provide for ease of provision of public safety and other municipal
services.
(Ord. 12, 2005, passed 7-11-2005)
§ 94.61 CHANGING NAME.
   The Council may, by ordinance, change the name of a street.
(Ord. 12, 2005, passed 7-11-2005)
§ 94.62 RECORDING STREET NAMES.
   Following adoption of an ordinance or plat naming or changing the name of a
street, the Clerk-Treasurer shall file a copy thereof with the County Recorder,
County Auditor, and County Assessor.
(Ord. 12, 2005, passed 7-11-2005)
§ 94.63 OFFICIAL STREET NAME MAP.
   Streets within the city are named as shown on the Official Street Name Map
which is hereby adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this chapter.
The Official Street Name Map shall be identified by the signature of the Mayor,
and bearing the seal of the city under the following words: “This is to certify
that this is the Official Street Name Map referred to in the Code of Ordinances
of Seymour, Indiana.”
(Ord. 12, 2005, passed 7-11-2005)
§ 94.64 REVISION OF MAP.
   If, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, changes are made in
street names, such changes shall be entered on the Official Street Name Map
promptly after the amendment has been approved by the Council with an entry on
the Official Street Name Map as follows: “On (date) by official action of the
City Council, the following changes were made in the Official Street Name Map:
(brief description),” which entry shall be signed by the Mayor and attested by
the Clerk. No amendment to this chapter which involves naming or changing the
name of a street shall become effective until after such change and entry has
been made on said map.
(Ord. 12, 2005, passed 7-11-2005)

   Hedges and live fences along public highways; trimming and maintaining, see
I.C. 32-26-4-1 et seq.
NUISANCES
§ 95.01 NUISANCE AND PUBLIC NUISANCE; ABATEMENT.
   (A)   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      NUISANCE. Any of the following:
         (a)   Activity which arises from unreasonable, unwarranted, or
unlawful use by a person of his or her own property, working obstruction or
injury to the right of another, or to the public, and producing such material
annoyance, inconvenience, and discomfort that will presume resulting damage;
         (b)   Everything that endangers life or health, gives offense to
senses, or obstructs reasonable and comfortable use of property;
         (c)   The class of wrongs that arise from the unreasonable,
unwarrantable, or unlawful use by a person of his or her own property, either
real or personal, or from his or her own improper or unlawful personal conduct,
working an obstruction of or injury to the right of another or of the public,
and producing such material annoyance, inconvenience, discomfort, or hurt, that
the law will presume resulting damage; or
         (d)   The term comprehends interference with an owner’s reasonable use
and enjoyment of his or her property by means of smoke, odors, noise, or
vibration, obstruction of private easements and rights of support, interference
with public rights, such as free passage along streams and highways, enjoyment
of public parks and places of recreation, and, in addition, activities and
structures prohibited as statutory NUISANCES.
      PUBLIC NUISANCE. A nuisance annoying that part of the public as
necessarily comes in contact with it or which is prejudicial to the general
public. It has also been stated that whatever obstructs the free use of
property, interfering with the comfortable enjoyment of life and property by an
entire community or neighborhood, is a PUBLIC NUISANCE. It may also be an
unreasonable interference with a right, common to the general public; it is
behavior which unreasonably interferes with the health, safety, peace, comfort,
or convenience of the general community.
   (B)   Any person violating any of the provisions of this subchapter shall be
guilty of a code violation. Each day a violation of this subchapter is
committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense. The
penalty for the offense shall be a fine for each day a person shall so fail,
refuse, or neglect to abate the nuisance, but in no case shall the aggregate of
these fines exceed $25,000.
   (C)   After any person shall have been convicted of erecting, causing,
keeping, continuing, or maintaining any public nuisance, the court may make it
a part of the judgment that the nuisance be abated at the cost of the person
convicted.
(1987 Code, § 6-142) (Ord. 10, 1990, passed 3-26-1990) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 95.02 EXCESSIVE NOISE FROM VEHICLES.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons operating upon any
street, alley, or public places in the city any automobile, motorcycle, or
other motor vehicle to at any time release or operate any attachment or
structurally alter the muffler or exhaust system, causing excessive and
unreasonable sound.
   (B)   Any person or persons convicted of the violation of the provisions of
this section shall be fined.
(1987 Code, § 6-141) (Ord. 668, passed 4-18-1911) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 95.03 BARBED WIRE FENCING.
   (A)   A barbed wire is declared to be unlawful, a nuisance, and a menace to
the public safety to erect, place, keep, or maintain as an outside fence.
   (B)   Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be
guilty of a code violation and upon conviction thereof shall be fined. Provided
further that each day the fence or fences shall be erected, kept, placed, or
maintained in violation of this section shall be deemed and treated as a
separate and distinct offense for which a separate prosecution may be
maintained.
   (C)   The agent or person in charge of any property on which any fence or
fences shall be maintained in violation of this section shall incur the penalty
prescribed.
(1987 Code, § 6-140) (Ord. 322, passed 9-23-1899) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 95.04 FIRE HYDRANTS; OBSTRUCTION OR TAMPERING.
   (A)   No person, not being authorized by the Chief of the Fire Department or
the Superintendent of the Water Department, shall open any fire plug or
hydrant, and no person place or deposit any building material or other
obstruction of any kind within ten feet of any fire plug or hydrant within the
city. No person shall, without authority from the Chief of the Fire Department
or the Superintendent of the Water Department draw or attempt to draw any water
from any fire plug or hydrant or obstruct, interfere with, or in any manner
tamper with any fire plug or hydrant.
   (B)   Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this section
shall on conviction be fined.
(1987 Code, § 6-143) (Ord. 693, passed 12-9-1912) Penalty, see §
10.99
 WEEDS AND RANK VEGETATION
§ 95.15 UNCUT WEEDS PROHIBITED; ABATEMENT.
   (A)   The owners of real property located within the city and the
unincorporated jurisdictional area, as shown on the city’s Jurisdictional Area
and Zone Map, are required to cut and remove weeds and other rank vegetation
growing on the property as provided herein.
   (B)   (1)   Weeds and rank vegetation shall be maintained at a height not to
exceed ten inches.
      (2)   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
         WEEDS AND OTHER RANK VEGETATIONS. The term does not include
agricultural crops, such as hay and pasture.
      (3)   (a)   A business entity within a designated industrial park, which
is participating in the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design ("LEED")
and/or the Sustainable Sites Initiative ("SITE") programs, and which can
demonstrate that it has received LEED and/or SITE certifications in one or more
other building projects owned or operated by such business entity in any other
location in the United States, shall be permitted to utilize natural and native
grasses on its real estate.
         (b)   The business entity must provide the City Building Commissioner
with evidence of its planned compliance with the scoring systems used in either
program; specifically addressing the effects that the sustainability project
will have on the community and environment.
         (c)   The benefit of compliance with this section shall be reduction
of water use because of planting and maintaining grasses native to the Southern
Indiana area.
         (d)   Because native grasses are similar in nature to pasture, these
grasses do not constitute weeds or rank vegetation; and further, these grasses
need not be mowed, which is consistent with growth in their natural
environment.
   (C)   The Board of Public Works and Safety of the city shall be responsible
for the administration of this subchapter.
   (D)   Upon determination of a violation of this subchapter by the Building
Commissioner or his or her agents, notice shall be given to the owner of the
real property of the condition constituting a violation, and requiring that the
weeds and rank vegetation be cut and removed within five days after receipt of
the notice. Notice shall be given by certified or registered mail, or any other
means available whereby proof of receipt thereof is procurable, including by
personal service.
   (E)   If the owner fails to abate the violation as stated in the notice of
violation, the city or its contractors may enter the real property immediately
or within a reasonable time after the owner’s failure to comply, during
daylight hours, to abate a violation of the subchapter.
(1987 Code, § 6-74) (Ord. 8, 1996, passed 3-11-1996; Am. Ord. 5, 2006, passed
6-26-2006; Am. Ord. 7, 2013, passed 6-10-2013; Am. Ord. 18, 2024, passed 5-28-
2024) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 95.16 ABATEMENT BY CITY; OWNER RESPONSIBLE FOR COSTS.
   (A)   Upon the city abating the violation, the city fiscal officer shall
issue a bill to the real property owner for the costs incurred by the city,
including administrative costs and removal costs.
   (B)   If the owner of real property fails to pay a bill issued under this
subchapter within 15 days, the Board of Public Works and Safety shall certify
to the County Auditor the amount of the bill plus any additional administrative
costs incurred in the certification. The Auditor shall place the total amount
certified on the tax duplicate for the property affected, and the total amount,
including any accrued interest, shall be collected as delinquent taxes are
collected and shall be disbursed to the General Fund of the city.
(1987 Code, § 6-75) (Ord. 8, 1996, passed 3-11-1996) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 95.17 APPEALS.
   (A)   The procedure for appealing a notice of violation or a bill issued
under this subchapter shall be by written notice to the Board of Public Works
and Safety, received prior to the time specified to respond or act in the
notice of violation or the bill issued, stating the reason for the appeal and
requesting a hearing by the Board of Public Works and Safety.
   (B)   A hearing shall be set by the Board of Public Works and Safety on a
business day no earlier than ten days after the request for hearing is
received.
   (C)   Each person may appear at the hearing in person or by counsel and is
entitled to present evidence, cross-examine opposing witnesses, and present
arguments.
   (D)   The decision of the Board of Public Works and Safety after hearing is
subject to review by the Circuit or Superior Court of the county. A person
seeking judicial review must file a complaint with the court within ten days of
the Board’s decision.
(1987 Code, § 6-76) (Ord. 8, 1996, passed 3-11-1996)
TREES AND SHRUBBERY
§ 95.30 DISTANCE FROM FIRE HYDRANTS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to plant,
keep, suffer, or permit any shrubbery or bushes within ten feet of any city
fire hydrant in the city.
   (B)   Any person, firm, or corporation found guilty of violating this
section shall, upon conviction, be fined.
(1987 Code, § 6-125) (Ord. 1080, passed 3-20-1945) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 95.31 TREE TRIMMING REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Cutting of live limbs from shade trees is prohibited, except the
cutting of the lower branches to a height of nine feet is permitted.
   (B)   Dead limbs from all trees must be cut and removed each year.
   (C)   The tops and limbs of all shade trees inside the corporate limits of
the city shall be trimmed so that they will not interfere with the light from
the street lights.
(Ord. 528, passed 11-30-1899)
   (D)   Any person, firm, or corporation violating this section shall be
guilty of a code violation and upon conviction thereof shall be fined.
(Ord. 916, passed 1-20-1927)
(1987 Code, § 6-126) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 95.32 TREE TRIMMING; PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to engage in
tree trimming, for hire, without first securing a permit so to do, as
hereinafter provided.
   (B)   Any person, firm, or corporation desiring to engage in the service of
tree trimming, for hire, shall file with the Clerk-Treasurer a general
performance bond in the minimum amount of $500 payable to the city, and
maintain public liability insurance in the minimum amount of $10,000 to
indemnify the public generally against loss or damage to person or property
through the negligence of the tree trimmers or their agents, servants, and
employees.
   (C)   Permits will be issued by the office of the City Clerk-Treasurer upon
request, without charge therefor, upon proof of clearance by the applicant as
to the specific tree trimming by the Chief of Police of this city.
   (D)   The Chief of Police may deny the clearance, until and unless that
person, firm, or corporation desiring to trim trees for hire shall furnish
satisfactory proof to the Chief of Police that the proposed tree trimming will
not interfere with or endanger traffic, whether vehicular or pedestrian, on any
public thoroughfare of this city.
   (E)   This section shall not apply to persons or individuals desiring to
trim trees on their own property.
   (F)   Any violation of this section shall be a code violation punishable
upon conviction by a fine.
(1987 Code, § 4-9) (Ord. 1467, passed 6-13-1966) Penalty, see §
10.99

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 96.01 AUTHORITY TO OPERATE.
   The city may establish, aid, maintain, and operate public parks,
playgrounds, and recreation facilities and programs.
(1987 Code, § 5-1)
Statutory reference:
   Authority to establish and maintain parks, see I.C. 36-10-2-2
§ 96.02 STATE LAW GOVERNS.
   The Park and Recreation Law found in I.C. 36-10-4-1 et seq. shall govern
operation of the Parks and Recreation Department.
(1987 Code, § 5-2)
§ 96.03 PARKS AND RECREATION BOARD; DUTIES.
   The powers of the Seymour Board of Parks and Recreation include:
   (A)   Enter into contracts and leases for facilities and services;
   (B)   Contract with persons for joint use of facilities for the operation of
park and recreation programs and related services;
   (C)   Contract with another board, a unit, or a school corporation for the
use of park and recreation facilities or services, and a township or school
corporation may contract with the Board for the use of park and recreation
facilities or services; acquire and dispose of real and personal property,
either within or outside Indiana;
   (D)   Exercise the power of eminent domain under statutes available to
municipalities;
   (E)   Sell, lease, or enter into a royalty contract for the natural or
mineral resources of land that it owns, the money received to be deposited in a
nonreverting capital fund of the Board;
   (F)   Engage in self-supporting activities as prescribed by this chapter;
   (G)   Contract for special and temporary services and for professional
assistance;
   (H)   Delegate authority to perform ministerial acts in all cases except
where final action of the Board is necessary;
   (I)   Prepare, publish, and distribute reports and other materials relating
to activities authorized by this chapter;
   (J)   Sue and be sued collectively by its legal name, as the "Seymour Park
and Recreation Board," with service of process being had upon the President of
the Board, but costs may not be taxed against the Board or its members in any
action;
   (K)   Invoke any legal, equitable, or special remedy for the enforcement of
this chapter, a park or recreation ordinance, or the Board's own action taken
under either;
   (L)   Release and transfer, by resolution, a part of the area over which it
has jurisdiction for park and recreational purposes to park authorities of
another unit for park and recreational purposes upon petition of the park or
recreation board of the acquiring unit;
   (M)   Make all rules and regulations, consistent with the laws of the state
and ordinances of the city for the establishment, operation, and maintenance of
the park and recreation facilities and park system within the city;
   (N)   The Board may also lease buildings or grounds belonging to the unit
and located within a park to a person for a period not to exceed 50 years. The
lease may authorize the lessee to provide upon the premises educational,
research, veterinary, or other proper facilities for the exhibition of wild or
domestic animals in wildlife parks, dining facilities, swimming facilities,
golf courses, skating facilities, dancing facilities, amusement rides generally
found in amusement parks, or other recreational facilities. A lease may be made
for more than one year only to the highest and best bidder, after notice that
the lease will be made has been given by publication in accordance with I.C. 5-
3-1;
   (O)   Notwithstanding division (N), the Board may lease buildings or grounds
belonging to the unit for a period of more than one year without soliciting the
highest and best bidder or providing notice under I.C. 5-3-1 if: the buildings
or grounds are leased to an Indiana nonprofit corporation; the buildings or
grounds are operated as a public golf course; and the golf course remains
subject to rules and regulations promulgated by the Board; and
   (P)   All other powers contained in the Park and Recreation statutes set
forth in the Indiana Code, specifically I.C. 36-10-3 et seq., as amended from
time to time.
(1987 Code, § 5-3) (Am. Ord. 4, 2004, passed 2-23-2004; Ord. 5, 2024, passed 3-
11-2024)
§ 96.04 SUPERINTENDENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION.
   (A)   Office created. There is created the office of Superintendent of Parks
and Recreation of the city.
(1987 Code, § 5-7)
   (B)   Appointment. The Superintendent of Parks and Recreation of the city
shall be appointed by the Mayor of the city, upon the recommendation and
subject to the approval of the City Council. The Superintendent shall also be
subject to removal by the Mayor of the city upon the recommendation of the
Parks and Recreation Committee of the City Council.
(1987 Code, § 5-8)
   (C)   Duties. The Superintendent of Parks and Recreation shall have
supervision over the parks of the city, shall be responsible for keeping the
parks clean and keeping the improvements and equipment in the parks in proper
repair. The Board shall approve all claims for materials and supplies purchased
for the parks and all claims for labor performed on the park property before
the claims are paid, and, in general, shall be responsible for the orderly
management of the park property.
(1987 Code, § 5-9)
(Ord. 1168, passed 2-25-1952)
   (D)   Salary of Superintendent. The salary of the Superintendent shall be
set by ordinance of the City Council.
(1987 Code, § 5-10)
Statutory reference:
   Superintendent; appointment and qualifications, see I.C. 36-10-3-13
   Superintendent; duties, see I.C. 36-10-3-14

35.15 of this code.
(1987 Code, § 5-40)

§ 96.07 LISTING OF PARK FACILITIES.
   The city offers the following parks and recreation facilities for use and
enjoyment by the public:
   (A)   Shields Park;
   (B)   Gaiser Park;
   (C)   Freeman Field;
   (D)   Kessler Park;
   (E)   City Cemetery;
   (F)   Community Center;
   (G)   Westside Park;
   (H)   One Chamber Square;
   (I)   Kasting Park;
   (J)   Steinker Platz; and

PARK RULES AND REGULATIONS
§ 96.20 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   All of the municipal parks of the city listed in §
96.07 of this code shall be open year round from 5:00 a.m. until midnight,
unless otherwise posted.
(1987 Code, § 5-32) (Ord. 25, 1992, passed 7-13-1992; Am. Ord. 40, 1998, passed
8-24-1998; Am. Ord. 12, 2018, passed 8-27-2018)
§ 96.21 ALCOHOL PROHIBITED.
   The possession and use of alcohol is prohibited in all park facilities
except as provided herein. Alcohol sales may be permitted for specific events
in Crossroads Park only by prior approval jointly by the Parks and Recreation
Department and the Board of Public Works and Safety. If alcohol sales are
permitted, the permittee shall be responsible for complying with all laws
concerning the sale and distribution of alcohol and shall provide adequate
insurance naming the City of Seymour as an additional insured for any damages
or liabilities arising out of the event.
(Ord. 12, 2018, passed 8-27-2018) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 96.22 SPECIAL HOURS USE PERMIT.
   The Superintendent of Parks and Recreation is expressly authorized to issue
a permit for any person or persons to specifically use the parks during the
periods of time they are not ordinarily open, provided the person or persons
applies in writing at least 12 hours in advance of the time the use is
requested.
(1987 Code, § 5-16) (Ord. 9, 1977, passed 7-11-1977)
§ 96.23 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons, without a permit as set out
in §
96.22 above, to be within the municipal parks at any time other than when the
parks are open for public use.
(1987 Code, § 5-17) (Ord. 9, 1977, passed 7-11-1977) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 96.24 VEHICLES PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to drive or operate any
motorized vehicle, within the municipal parks at any time, provided that this
prohibition shall not apply to park or other municipal employees while in the
performance of their official duties.
(1987 Code, § 5-18) (Ord. 35, 1978, passed 11-27-1978; Am. Ord. 12, 2018,
passed 8-27-2018) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 96.25 DEFACEMENT OF PROPERTY PROHIBITED.
   The defacement of any property of the parks is specifically prohibited.
Failure to abide by the provisions of this section can result in the
instituting of criminal charges against the violator.
(1987 Code, § 5-34) (Ord. 25, 1992, passed 7-13-1992) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 96.26 INTERFERENCE WITH ANIMALS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to pursue, throw at, or shoot at any
squirrels or birds or to interfere with their nesting places or to climb any
trees.
(1987 Code, § 5-20) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 96.27 DOGS RUNNING AT LARGE PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog to permit that animal to run
at large in the park at any time.
(1987 Code, § 5-21) (Ord. 836, passed 8-4-1922) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 96.28 METAL DETECTORS.
   The use of metal detectors in park facilities is acceptable provided that
they are not used in any part of any ball field at any of the parks.
(Ord. 12, 2018, passed 8-27-2018) Penalty, see §
10.99
